Getting seated is not difficult - there have been nights with the place half-empty, and other nights where we've had to wait a bit but it's not too bad.
author: Joe M.

description:
The fourth law of dinner: Confusion while selecting a restaurant always increases the volatility of the result.

In this case, I confused Ariake with another Japanese restaurant nearby. But I decided to give it a shot anyway. The bar (sushi in SF) was high and Ariake ended up a little flat.

The salmon  tasted fishy and the uni wasn't as flavorful as it should be. Apart from that, it was A-OK!

I give it a worth trying if you're drunk.
author: Richard B.

description:
When I first stepped into this restaurant for an early dinner, I was greeted with a friendly greeting by more than one staff member, which set the happy mode or mood for me to dine here. Plus, I thought one or two of the waitresses working here was really cute.

Anyways, I get seated and am given plenty of time to order. I ordered a few rolls, but none really stood out to me except for the Godzilla one because the other ones were good, but I've had better. So I definitely plan on coming back and ordering a few of the Godzilla rolls. 

I only took one star away because I've felt it's pretty pricey to dine here, so might not come too often, but occasionally.
author: Pudgy G.

description:
Tiny portions.  Horrible service.

We ordered the lunch bento box with three items: salmon teriyaki, salmon sashimi, and tuna sashimi.  The waitress (who later turned out to be the owner) said no, "you can only choose one sashimi item.". OK, no problem, since bento boxes are set prices, so she's probably trying to keep the cost down.  "We can pay you extra." "No, sorry," came her polite but stern reply.  WHY NOT?  I just don't understand people who leave money on the table.  

The service aside from that was equally lacking.  We had to fetch our own menus, and ask for hot tea.  What's next?  Wash our own dishes?

It's not even an one hit wonder.  It's an one hit miss.  Goodbye Ariake.
author: Kristen S.

description: This is a review for take-out only. It was Friday night and we wanted sushi, but didn't feel like making the trek down to our normal place. Since Ariake is right across the street from our place, we decided to give it a try. We got some maki rolls, which is what we normally eat when we have sushi. The size of the rolls was pretty decent-- about what I've been used to seeing other places. There were some interesting maki rolls that I hadn't seen before, so we tried some of those, and some more classic ones. The different ones were interesting, and not bad. The sushi overall just wasn't the same quality that I'm used to having. It wasn't bad, but I probably won't be back.
author: Jess B.

description: When I first walked inside, the waitresses were very welcoming and they were really nice. We sat around the bar area with the sushi chefs around and the food that they displayed was very fresh. The fish was also delicate and fresh. The chefs are very kind and welcoming as well. They have different varieties of raw fish and the chefs will tell you if they're in season or not! Do talk to them if you can! They're really nice! Everyone in general had such a nice positive vibe plus the food was very wonderful. I really recommend this place for good sushi!
author: Ricky K.

description: This place is always so good every time I go! The sushi always tastes so fresh and I love the atmosphere here.
author: K M.

description: This small but friendly restaurant sports delicious cuts of high quality fish. The sushi is expertly crafted by talent artisan chefs and delivered by a knowledgeable and outgoing wait staff. The signature rolls are amongst the best in the city and the nigiri cuts are rich and flavorful. Call for a reservation because this small restaurant fills up quickly!
author: Mike S.

description: Really gone down hill over the last 5 years. I probably will never go back after two recent experiences with low quality fish. The cuts were so bad I didn't even finish my nigiri.
author: Q C.

description:
Exceptional.. I mean don't come in and just order one dumb roll and a filler item like tempura.. or something fried..
Read the board with all the fresh fish they are showcasing and order it and eat something really delicious.  First class sushi work both by the owner and his chefs.
and wife is host and very nice.
author: Adam O.

description: Wonderful, authentic sushi!!! A perfect, little lunch spot with a phenomenal selection of fish! Their fish are incredibly fresh and their sushi chefs are very knowledgable. The saki and beer selection are also extraordinary!
author: S V.

description: Firecracker roll, Tataki salad and the Lion King are what sushi dreams are made of.
author: Geri C.

description:
Loved it!

Only been here once, had the chirashi and it was really good. Everything was really fresh.

Service was okay.

Really small place though, so the wait might be a while.
author: Erica L.

description: Some of the sushi was fantastic (especially anything they recommended). Some of the sushi was just OK (especially the Unagi, which was chewy). Service was ... hectic.
author: Morris R.

description:
Awesome sushi spot and totally worth the drive if you don't live nearby. Service is lovely.

One of the best bowls of miso I've ever had (there needs to be a perfect balance of miso and salty - they mastered it). 

I loved the Hamachi Mango and Double Albacore rolls. Apparently the Moon Dog is *the best* but the good lord gave me shellfish allergies. Tons of awesome shellfish rolls on the menu, too. Everything else we had was super fresh; yummy Maguro and Toro sashimi.

Note: He's currently getting his fish from Greece which says something about his conscience and his concern for the health consequences of his customers. Kudos to him for thinking about this during a time when most people wouldn't realize why this is so important...
author: Meredith R.

description:
LOVE THIS PLACE TO DEATH! If you know what great sushi is, come to this place. Get the Moondog or Hamachi Mango. This is one of the freshest fish I've ever had! I seriously can't go to another sushi rest after this place... Everyone is so nice and welcoming. So if you plan on going here get the sushi rolls! The bento box is good too but their SPECIALTY is the sushi guarantee!!!! :) 

And GET THE GREEN TEA CHEESE CAKE! THEE BEST!
author: Stephen H.

description:
This is the BEST sushi place in the Richmond, hands down. Out of all the sushi places in the Richmond, this one is hand's down the best. The fish is really fresh, the service is on point, everyone is friendly and provides great service! I've always had great experiences here and after trying all the other sushi restaurants that are a bit closer to my apartment, I've finally decided to stop wasting my time and money on poor food, poor service, or both. 

If you don't live in the Richmond, this place is still completely worth the drive or bus ride. Fabulous!!
author: Brenna S.

description:
I saw some of the reviews and thought I should write about this place. For one, I don't understand why people let $ become a factor for the review. I get that price can be a big deal, but come on, you can check out the menu and know if you can afford to eat there or not. Duh. This shouldn't be factored into whether the food tastes good or not. 

Second, what's with factoring race? If Koreans made sushi, big deal. If it tastes good, I'm so there. You see non-Asians at Panda Express making Chinese food, but people still go there...just sayin'.  

OK. End Rant. Now onto the restaurant review...

I've been coming here for at least the last 5 years. I haven't been disappointed and although the sushi could fluctuate once in a while (the new sushi chef behind the counter, not Jin, sometimes doesn't put the masago on top of my rolls), the taste is always the same. 

The restaurant is small, so sometimes you have to wait for a table. But if I had to rate the place  solely on the space and the cost of the sushi, I would not give it 5 stars, maybe more like 3 or 4 on atmosphere. But I'm rating on the quality of the fish and service, so I give this place 5 stars. Sushi is pricey to begin with, but it doesn't mean this place costs an arm and a leg. It's about the same anywhere, but the fish is always fresh and my tea cup is always full. The waitresses are really nice and attentive, even when they are busy. 

My favorite rolls I order that I can't find elsewhere are:

Moondog Roll
Island Roll (Really like this roll because of the thinly sliced lemon they put on top of it really gives you a fresh burst of citrus that complements the salmon coupled with the crunch from the tempura shrimp). 
Hamachi Mango (Mango and fish?! Who knew the combo would be so noms!)
Cliff House (although this is no longer on the menu, but they still make it for me :) )

If you get bored of regular rolls, this place has a few that you won't find anywhere else. And if you become a regular, JIn remembers you and will strike up a conversation with you if you sit at the bar.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Kabuto was closed on Monday, poo

So I
Stumble into Ariake
Don't use the menu
Order off the signs behind the chefs

Toro Nigiri
Hamachi Mango
Firecracker
Dynamite 
King Salmon Nigiri

Chef sent out salmon skin - delicious!
red snapper
halibut 
shima aji
yellow jack
and more halibut!

As you can see this led to some random orders :( But it all ended well!

The sushi here is so fresh but what made it better was the chef explained each fishes flavor type and steered me into my beloved halibut! 

They also cut fat slices an order of nigiri here will get you about 2x other places as well as placing shiso leave in some!

All for under 100 bucks!

Come hungry, come curious, and let the chefs guide you.

you can also go k-style and order sesame oil and red pepper paste!

just when I thought sf did not have fresh sushi I found a gem :')
author: Daniel K.

description:
Delicious !!!!!! 
Everything was beautifully plated and the sushi was just marvelous.
My only complaint is that they don't have hot green tea :( I need my tea with my sushi
author: Alan T.

description:
If you want amazingly fresh high quality sushi in the city without a super high price tag, this is it!! Their kitchen food options are a good too :} and so is the service

Shima Aji, must try! And all the other fish, sake, hon hamachi, is great n fresh.

Get the large portion of tuna tataki and it's huge! (for tuna tataki, not talking hungryman tv dinner here) Not the best tuna tataki I've ever had, but decent.

Lion King roll was it? With salmon and lemon zest on top, simple but wonderful.

The Ariake roll, spicy tuna roll with seaweed salad on top, is also priced nicely and is a staple to my orders. Of course not too much mayo in the spicy tuna roll that the roll looks more orange than red like the shat sushi joints.

I also love one of the sushi chefs, talked to him briefly bout his nutty times in Miami in his youth. He was sad when he told me he wished SF had parties that went all night long, boy was he in for a surprise. 



He'll make it public that the Shima Aji from Japan is his favorite (mine too), as he can't resist to slip a piece in his mouth he exclaims "esss soo gewwww"
author: Belito L.

description:
We came at around 9:30pm and waited a few minutes to get our name in for a table. It was not overly busy but the service seemed to be a bit slow. The food however came out fresh and timely once we got our order in. 

We ordered 4 rolls: Crazy Roll, Moon Dog, Lion King, and the Island roll. All delicious! 

We would have given four stars but the lack of service knocked them down a star. *they were not rude or anything, it just seemed like they kept forgetting we were there.
author: Pork N.

description: Solid sushi, probably the best I've had in the Richmond. Will definitely be my go to sushi spot now. Chefs are super friendly too and do a great job of explaining the rolls, fish and everything in between. So tasty and fresh.
author: Zo M.

description:
Korean owned Japanese restaurant with many Causasian patrons. 

Decent tonkatsu dish but on the pricier side $14 (normally it is $12?).  Spider roll was decent but wished I could of eaten Tuna instead. 

Narrow space, the biggest table sat 8 people?
author: Jboogie L.

description:
Okay. This place... I can't even... just -- go there. The exterior does not at all betray the cornucopia of deliciousness that resides within. This is a true-blue hole in the wall restaurant. The staff is adorable and incredibly polite. The owner, Jin, imports fish a few times a week. If he's working the sushi bar, you can ask him what's fresh/what he'd recommend and he will go into obscene detail as to why, say, the tuna is the best that night.

I've been here a few times with a friend and her husband, and the food has never failed to be anything but incredible. First off, we have ankimo. Monkfish liver. Those not seasoned in sushi may cringe at the thought, but this stuff is SO AMAZING. It's buttery and smooth -- not at all what you might expect from well... liver. If you're brave enough, give it a go -- it's definitely not the cheapest thing on the menu, but very much worth every penny.

Next, hamachi kama. This is the cheek/neck of Yellowtail, and Ariake does it right. The meat falls off like it was placed there by hand, and each bite is like a miniature megaton of flavor. 

They have kuramoro oysters with a great house sauce. This is a great place to start if you want to try oysters! The sauce compliments the flavors of oysters, which are surprisingly sweet -- not briny, and not at all what I expected.

In terms of rolls, the only ones I've had are the Ariake and Moon Dog. I... probably won't even bother trying anything else, because those two knock it out of the park.

Now if you're in the mood to spend a bit of money, and you're a fan of sake, indulge in the Narutotai. It comes in a 700~ mL steel bottle, and it is likely the best sake you will find on this side of the Pacific. I've rarely appreciated notes of flavor in sake (as it was usually going down with a Kirin or Ichiban in a sake bomb). Narutotai is AMAZING. The stuff is imported, however, and comes at $65 a bottle.
author: Taylor S.

description: Mmm super fresh uni is the best way to gauge a great sushi spot. Small intimate wo that usual Geary street Japanese restaurant mentality of "more and bigger is bertter" this spot serves real good quality worthwhile fresh sushi in authentic portion size. Pricier than Geary street sushi bars but well worth it and attentive service. Mmm mm. Can't wait to go again.
author: Sabina W.

description:
We were looking for a place to go, it's Saturday night around 9. There were 10 and we were walking down Geary and found this place. It's a really small place but they are willing to accommodate us and they close pretty late. Granted that it was pretty packed, it took them forever to get us seated.

We had couple of rolls and honestly they were good but the service turned me off. They weren't friendly with us.

I might give them another shot next time, but we'll see.
author: Czarina Y.

description:
Came with a friend for a casual sushi dinner - #obsessedwithsushi. 

Ariake has been on my to-try list for awhile now and it's super close to where I live. So finally, on a weekday, Ariake was calling my name. 

Ariake has very fresh nigiri and nice sushi chefs (unlike some nazi sushi places). They even gave us extra salmon sashimi and there's free edamame to start. 

We ordered:

1. Gyoza - 3/5 
Average gyoza, crispy and duricious - paired with slightly spicy soy sauce

2. 10 pcs of salmon sashimi - 4/5
My friend really liked it. I tried a piece as well and it was very fresh. Though the cuts were pretty small compared to other sushi places I've seen. 

3. King salmon nigiri - 5/5 
My favorite type of nigiri along with Japanese butterfish. Very fresh and portion size was generous. Liked that the chef didn't pack the nigiri full of rice.

4. Hon (natural) Hamachi nigiri - 5/5
Really liked that they have Hon Hamachi and not just Hamachi. Melts in your mouth delicious. 

5. Uni with quail egg - 3/5
The uni with quail egg was packed very generously and creamy but it was not as good or as unique as Koo. But if you want no frills Uni with quail egg, this is def a legit option. 

I would come back to Ariake again if I don't want to wait in a long line (Tekka) or pay $$$ for sushi (Kabuto). Ariake is a very good option for mid-range priced sushi bar around the Golden Gate area. 

PS. Sushi chefs were really chill but the servers were really sloooowww..we had to ask for menus (??) twice before it came.
author: Lily S.

description: We've lived in the richmond for years and went into this restaurant for the first time based on the good reviews. I ordered chirashi lunch. The rice was very hard and dry and the fish pieces very small. Very disappointed.
author: El L.

description: Wasn't that great. They put carrots in the spicy tuna roll, which dominated the flavors. Salmon teriyaki was below average. Dynamite roll was decent. 3 stars for nice waiter and cleanliness of the place.
author: Melanie C.

description:
As you might imagine, there are hundreds of places to go for sushi in the city, so my girlfriend and I feel a little silly always going back to the saaaame place week in and week out. But every time we try somewhere new, we keep running right back to Ariake. This past weekend we tried Elephant sushi, which according to Yelp is the #2 sushi place in the city, and it's a great place, but I'd still take Ariake any day of the week.

The chefs Jim, Young, and Shaun (forgive the misspellings) are all very friendly, and their selection of fish is unrivaled. As a Japanese guy, I'm hard pressed to use the terms "favorite sushi bar ever," but I honestly cannot think of anywhere I've had better sushi (and yes, I am aware the chefs aren't Japanese. Doesn't matter).

Note: We do all nigiri and sashimi style orders at places with high quality fish, so I have no comment on the rolls at this place. My typical order usually includes at least a few "surprise me, whatever's freshest" nigiri orders, and the Madagas Rogue Shrimp.
author: James Y.

description:
I've been in New Zealand for awhile, but NEVER miss a meal at Ariake when I come back to San Francisco.  I used to be here every Friday night when I lived in town.  Jin has an amazing source for his fish--the hamachi is buttery and flavorful.  I've never had better hamachi, even in Japan!  Try the grilled hamachi kama(cheek)--wonderful.

The place is small and casual, but delivers big in the way of incredibly fresh and delicious dishes.  The 49er roll is THE best ever--Jin makes it with japanese herb in the middle (shiso), and paper thin lemon slices on the outside of the salmon.  Also, the tuna tataki is AMAZING.  I could go on and on...
author: Marti G.

description:
Looking for a Late-Night Sushi Place - you've found the right place.  It's a little hole in the wall, not too spacious for groups.

They serve with only the FRESHEST ingredients.  Therefore don't expect to be stuffed full without a hefty bill, their QUALITY definitely valued greater than QUANTITY.

Agedashi Tofu - so fresh, literally served at cooking temperature [so the anxious me, dives for a piece and burns my mouth - ___ -]

Hamachi Mango - various colored tobiko.  Mango wasn't too sweet because it wasn't in season.  But the Hamachi was very fresh, almost melted in my mouth!

Firecracker - MUST TRY, its so UNIQUE.  The seaweed is covered with tempura batter (but it's actually not heavy AT ALL), covered with spicy tuna, fresh seaweed salad and topped with tobiko.  SO DELICIOUS (I wish we ordered more)

Moondog (what an odd name) - it was so good.  It consisted of crunchy shrimp tempura (I'm very hesitant of tempura in my sushi since I fear excessive batter), cucumber topped with seared tuna and this special sauce they made.

Ahh, if I ever need a snack in between my big meals and is in the neighborhood, I will definitely come back!
author: Steph L.

description:
The best sushi I have ever had.  Get the Toro, the Bluefin, the natural hamachi and salmon.

I've had expensive-ass sushi in Japan. This tops everything though.  Don't miss this place.  Excellent service.
author: Jackson B.

description: One of my to-go places for sushi. Service was friendly. Waitress recommended the best and freshest fish that they had. She kept saying "oh it's fresh, just came in today!" So much enthusiasm. She was right because the o-toro, hamachi, tuna were pretty good. Also ordered dragon roll, monkfish and some other raw fish appetizers. They definitely excelled in the raw fish dept, which was all recommended by the waitress however the dragon roll was just average. I would have probably skipped the green tea cheesecake and just would have ordered the green tea ice cream instead. The restaurant seats no more than 30 people, smaller scale, very intimate. Lastly, 100 health score! I would definitely come back again for their awesome fresh sashimi!
author: J C.

description: Really nice selection of very fresh fish. Basically asked the sushi chef to just feed us and 15+ pieces of nigiri later, had a full belly and a smile on my face. The Tai, big-eye toro, and kampachi were particularly delicious. The live scallop was literally like butter, rich and sweet. And the owner was very friendly and down-to-earth; he even tried to talk us into a less expensive Sake than the one we ordered.
author: Doctor S.

description: I was craving sushi and my friend brought me here. They get a solid 3.5 stars. All the specialty rolls were good, tempura was ok and the chicken skews were ok. Bummer, they don't have butterfish!!
author: Karen T.

description:
I wandered into this place tonight with a hankering for some good sushi.  I live in this neighborhood and had never thought to eat here, but OMG I was denying myself!  The sushi is prepared cleanly, the fresh, lush colors are gorgeous too look and the taste is heavenly!  The service is awesome, and my green tea never got  chance to get cold because the servers were so quick to top me off!  That to me is AMAZING.

I would definitely visit this place again in a heartbeat.  This is as good as it gets for neighborhood hot spots!  My recommendation: order the Ariake signature sushi roll as a starter: it's a great flavor, it's light and its fresh taste is a great way to whet the appetite.  I had the Moon Dog roll for dinner and it was so damn good.  This fat kid is a happy fat kid!  

I will be back with plenty of hungry friends.
author: Robyn J.

description:
Usually Im not a big sushi person. I havent been for  a long time. I think this is primarily because I never get full off of them. I always leave the restaurant hungry regardless of how many rolls i eat, no joke (Im fairly thin too). And, I really don't know why this happens. The last time I went to a sushi place in Santa Barbara, our group ended up walking down the street right after to a Thai place where we continued our dinner. :)
Anyway, I have been to Ariake twice and always left happy. Rolls are VERY tasty and filling! My favorite sushi roll here is the Dragon roll. 
The service here is also very good. They refill hot tea cups constantly which is a big plus for me, since I drink tea with most of my meals. :)
The restaurant is small, so there is not a lot of space for many people, but its very cute and inviting!
author: Yuliya K.

description: This place delivers every time I go here. the food is great and the service is great. sushi is always super fresh and yummy. I'm not sure why some other yelpers are giving them a 1star rating for a billing mistake or not refilling their cups... really? i could care less about your bitching and complaining - its the food i care about. if you need more tea, then get your butt up and ask for it and they will run right over. if you have a wrong charge, call your bank and cancel the whole transaction or have them adjust it... not hard, is it? get over your selves people.
author: Alex M.

description: This was our first time at Ariake and it will be a regular place for us if we find parking. I love Bento box lunch and this one was done perfectly to my taste. Light , crunchy tempura and the beef is rib eye . Nice quiet environment where you can talk to your dinner companion.
author: Linda C.

description:
A lil pricey.

Came here on Saturday night. Three waitresses and three sushi chefs, which two were owners I believe. A very small restaurant and I'm surprised to see so many workers. Service was awesome bc of the size of restaurant. 

If u don't want to spend a lot of money for Japanese food i wouldn't recommend coming here. My bf and I had a large plate of tuna and an ariake sushi plate with one glass of plum wine to share = $65 with tax/tip. Very pricey. The ariake sushi plate ($26) had like 20 pieces of sushi, seems like a lot right?? Nope bc 6 of them as California rolls and 6 as small tuna rolls. So theres only 8 pieces Nigiri.  
But fishes were fresh. Wasabi was also fresh as well. Not from a bottle. 

Size of restaurant is small so there will be waits on weekends. Not recommended for parties more than 4 people. When you go there you will understand why.
author: Tammy F.

description:
The Yelp star rating thing says 'Woohoo! As good as it gets!' for five stars. This is how I feel about this place. The fish is always fresh, the service is awesome, the price is fine, and they remember you when you come back.

Their rolls are great but I love the nigiri here. My favorites are Shima Aji and the Sea Bream (blanking on the name right now, will have to update later).

I've brought big and small parties here and have always had great service. If you do have a larger party call ahead and make reservations. If it's just 1-2 people you can probably bounce in without much of a wait. That's been my experience anyway.

I love this place!
author: Brody K.

description: The service was a little awkward (the waitress gave me the check even I didn't ask for. What I did was ordering something more expensive and leave the check alone, then she took the check away by herself) but this restaurant is the only one that shows the right amount of tips so far (%*total before tax). I think it's owned by Koreans while the food was good. The chefs were courteous.
author: Grizabella L.

description: Expensive for what you get. Service is terrible. For such a small place I don't see how they can't handle a crowd. Asked for water...did not get water. Asked to order...the server walks away in the middle of your order and forgets about you. Food is average...small portions. You might want to get a pizza afterwards.
author: Tina S.

description:
The "Love" chirashi sushi was okay, but the sushi rice could have used more vinegar flavoring in my opinion. Also, for the white tuna, maybe I've been spoiled recently but I was disappointed they didn't serve the type that's pure white in color, which I like better.

Actually, the other night I only came here by chance. I was going to Kabuto to try the foie gras on their menu before the upcoming ban. Unfortunately it was full, and though there were no other parties waiting I didn't see the likelihood of anyone leaving soon at the time. Therefore I gave up and decided to give this place a try.
author: H K.

description: Having uni with quail eggs and plum wine!!! Very good service and food is great very casual and the price is right!
author: Ty N.

description:
My bento box was quite worth the price. I had the tempura with salmon sashimi. This place serves one of the freshest sashimi I have eaten in San Francisco. However, the reason why I didn't give them a four star rating is because I find it a rip off ordering the Sashimi Combo A. Although I wasn't the one who ordered it, I felt really bad for my friend who did. They barely give you anything. It's so not worth $15! 

Service was okay. The chef said, "hello" so I responded back with a "hi." After that, he didn't say anything so it just made it very awkward sitting alone at the table as I waited for my friend to arrive.
author: Forest T.

description:
The Moon Dog is still the best item on their menu ~ a must try for everyone!  Bob's was pretty good as well and their sashimi is really fresh.

When there is a full house, service is not as great - my tea cup was always empty and I had to ask 3x before it got refilled =/  May not be such a great place to chill but still a great place for sushi.
author: Katelynn L.

description:
Understated. Straightforward. Mild-mannered.

Simply put, Ariake is great. No frills, fresh fish, and no rolls heavily doused in saccharine sweet-mayo. Similarly, the ambiance is no frills and clean.

Unique dish - monkfish foie gras? (aka fish liver) Imagine consistency of amateur foie gras with a slightly overwhelming fish flavor. 

Must have - Sashimi - melts in your mouth. Conducive for dates as this eliminates fish-hanging-from-mouth-as-you-try-to-bite-through-it potential. Bite right through, sista.

Noteworthy - Hamachi Mango Asparagus roll - refreshing flavor, delicately dressed with sauce, artistically topped with sparkling roe gems.

$$10-15/roll
author: Jane L.

description:
We were cold and hungry and Ariake innocently offered open seats as we dropped in for an early dinner. 

Once inside and warmed with steaming green tea, we were prepared to eat.

We started with rolls to share:
- Hamachi Mango ($12): Alternating slices of sweet ripe mango and yellowtail striped across the back of rice, with more mango and asparagus rolled inside, with some tasty sauce and tri-colored roe in orange, green and black on top. The mango tended to overpower the fish but pretty presentation.

- Double Albacore: This was one of the chalkboard specials. Fresh albacore sat on top and inside the roll for a creamy mouthful. 

- Firecracker ($7): You get 4 pieces of tempura shiso leaves which serve as the carrier for spicy tuna mix with a little seaweed wakame salad on top. This was my favorite with its various textures and heated flavors.

We also shared some Nabeyaki Udon ($9.95) which had deliciously flavorful broth, chewy udon noodles, and the usual fixings of veggie, chicken, and tempura shrimp inside.

Friendly service, frequented by regulars, and well priced to invite you back for more. (3.75 stars for hitting the spot and wallet.)
author: Cindy W.

description:
This is one of my favorite Sushi spots. I used to live just down the street, and my old roomie and I would frequent this spot if we were craving sushi.  Now that I no longer live in the 'hood,' I still try and hit up Ariake as often as I can. It's also been a tradition that my old roomie and I go there for our respective birthday outings. 

Most of the clientele here are locals. I've even brought my mom, who is a picky eater, to Ariake, and she now calls it one of her favs!

Anyway, I'm all about the sush, as it is always fresh. I recommend the tataki (white tuna) salad, as it's one of my favorite dishes. It is delish, and I love how the lemon wedges bring out the flavor in each bite. Another fav of mine is the hamachi. Oh, it just melts in your mouth! Make sure to see what their daily specials are. I'm a mango freak, and there was a special sushi roll with mango and hamachi (if memory serves me right). Oh mylanta!!! Truly divine!

Service is good. Servers and sushi chefs are friendly and efficient. I recommend going early for dinner to beat the rush.
author: Gill C.

description: When I used to live in the neighborhood over 10-years ago, I had a more forgiving palate.  This place was good to me.  Now, it's just flavorless fish and sushi rice not done right.  The staff is pleasant and service is good and most people seem to enjoy it.  Not for sushi snobs put perfectly fine who like rolls and those that put too much soy sauce and wasabi on their sushi.  #K-ownedSushi
author: Laurence H.

description:
Two nights of sushi in a row! I've always wanted to try here since it's like three blocks from my house. Glad I chose to come here the other night! It was super busy for a Thursday night around 730. The place is small with just a couple tables for 4 and a sushi bar. We got seated right where the door was and it was freezing! 

We kept looking at what everyone was eating and started drooling. Everything looked so good but we decided on trying these items:
Moon Dog Roll ($12) - Shrimp tempura and crab with seared tuna on top and their special sauce
Spider Roll ($9) - soft shell crab with veggies.
   I've had better spider rolls but it was still tasty.. They didn't skimp on the soft shell crab!
Dynamite Roll ($7) - Yellow tail, salmon, tuna, lightly deep fried. 
  So good but the outside fried goodness had just a little too much batter on it so it was really thick.
Island Roll ($12) - Crab and shrimp tempura with salmon and avocado and lemon on top. 
  MmMMmmm yummy fresh salmon with that thin slice of lemon taste so good together!!!!

The prices for those special rolls are pretty pricey but it was worth it. Really good. I wish I would get my tea BEFORE I get my food next time?
author: Juliane N.

description: We had a sushi crisis tonight when we called our usual spot, and they said they are no longer delivering. Yikes!  We gave Ariake a try because they are 3 blocks away, and we loved everything that we ordered.  So good that we'll skip our usual spot and start ordering from Ariake from now on.
author: A W.

description:
A different pace of sushi bars...

Jin used to work at the long standing Ebisu over in the inner Sunset before opening up his own place - Ariake.

It's been awhile since I've climbed up onto the stools of Ariake's sushi bar to enjoy the fish here.  It was a quiet Wednesday night, not too busy, but a steady stream of regulars coming in throughout the evening.  There was even a space heater near the front to warm those customers seated near the doorway.

We were seated immediately and were greeted with warm disposable towels. Edamame was placed between my dining partner and I.  First thing I noticed, the cleaniness of the fish assortment before my eyes.  The display case was neat, and the fish weren't just tossed in there.  Even all the 'sides' on the counter behind the display case were laid out with care.  I definitely appreciate this in a restaurant.

We started with the Bonito Sashimi with creamy sauce.  I definitely enjoy how Ariake does it.  There was a plentiful amount of fish, tobiko eggs, and creamy sauce (without being runny).  It was oh so yummy!  Next was Firecracker - deep fried shiso leaf with seaweed salad and poki on it.  Yummy, and a nice contrast of flavors.  

We also ordered Uni nigiri, Hamachi nigiri, and Ikura nigiri.  It was good, not fabulous, but good.  My sister also had a Natto roll that I stayed far away from.  The smell alone turns me off!  Bleh!  

We closed with a 49er roll - salmon, avocado, mint leaves, and lemon slices.  Refreshing and tasty, quite enjoyable.

The green tea ice cream tasted even better than what I recall other places offering.  Perhaps it was the creaminess?  I'm not sure, but it was good.

Service is at a slower pace here, but my tea cup was always full for the most part.  (And I do drink lots of tea when I'm dining.)  If you're in a rush, I wouldn't recommend eating here then.  Go when you have time to spare.

With the low music playing in the background, I enjoyed this quieter side of eating sushi.  The last few times I've sat at the bar at other restaurants, I was surrounded by loud, obnoxious and overbearing patrons.  It was a relief and comforting to be able to enjoy my meal without being subjugated to everyone else's dramatics.  

In the past, I've had some hits and misses with Ariake's.  But last night, they were more on the hit and I would definitely go back.

Side note: I used to bring my friend here who became addicted to their Toro.  He would come here on his own, daily, weekly, whenever he wanted a taste of Toro.  He became known to them as Toro Boy.  He then started bringing his friends along, and in turn, one of his friends 'introduced' his favorite SF sushi place to me - Ariake's, on a date.  I had to laugh, the power of networking had come full circle.  I had to break it to him, I had been the one who brought Toro Boy to Ariake's in the first place. And in turn, it's really my sister's fault 'cuz she found out first Jin had opened this place up.
author: Teri C.

description: Love this place. My recommendation: sit at the bar and shoot the shit with the chef. Order nigiri from the wall behind him. Those are often the freshest fish. If in doubt, ask. They are really welcoming and will give you great food.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: Their maguro mango and hamachi mango rolls are to die for.
author: Johan S.

description: Went here last month, the food was just ok(not bad) I was disappointed, seriously not worth it $$$ the price are too high, I ordered the hamachi Kama, I found that they charged it $21. I probably would not recommend a friend to this place, why? I can get better but cheaper food some other place, why should I come here?
author: Andy Z.

description:
This is nice japanese restaurant.
We had a few bottles of sake and the owner gave us good suggestions. 
The food was good and reasonably priced. I would definately go back.
author: Larry V.

description:
Bad Japanese food !!!

My friend treated me to lunch there last Tuesday, 6/10/14, at 1pm.  Although the waiter was prompt and courteous, he gave us bad recommendations for cooked rolls.  They ignored my request for light or no sauce.  The space was tiny and cramped (4 tables and a few chairs at the sushi bar).  We found the food intolerably sweet or salty, overcooked, oversauced, and sloppily prepared.  My review is based on 3 items we ordered:

--Dinner item #10. Sukiyaki: sliced beef, glass noodle, & vegetables cooked in broth.  It came with miso soup, salad and rice.  Intolerably SWEET broth, excessive onion (1/2 of a big one), good tofu and beef slices.  I could not drink such sugary broth despite my eternal love for soup.  5/10. 

--Sushi bar special #5. Lion King: crab meat, avocado, wrapped salmon baked.  Recommended by the waiter, so shame on him.  SALTY, OVERCOOKED, OVERSAUCED, MESSY.  They overbaked the roll and added excessive salt and mayo/eel sauce.  They baked the whole roll in aluminum foil and served the roll atop the foil, instead of baking only the salmon and then preparing the roll with the baked salmon.  With the same ingredients, Yuubi offers Pink Dragon roll - beautifully presented, clean, tasty, & cheaper.  4/10

--Sushi bar special #12. Cliff House: crab meat, avocado topped with baked
seafood.  Recommended by the waiter, so shame on him.  OVERCOOKED, OVERSAUCED, MESSIER AND SLOPPIER than Lion King roll.  4/10

The poor-quality food would keep me away forever.  Us included, there were only 3 occupied tables during the lunch rush hour on the busy Geary block.  Why come here when you can get better and cheaper Japanese food closeby at Yuubi, Tanuki, or Ebisu.
author: G D.

description: Great quality fish. Uni is yummy here. Live sea scallops are delicious. My favorite Japanese sushi place.
author: Albert M.

description:
My boyfriend and I were excited to come back here after an afternoon of shopping downtown.  We strolled in to a 3/4 full restaurant around 6:30pm and sat at the bar since we didn't call ahead.  We ordered the exact same thing we got the first time we were here, Maguro and Hamachi Nigiri and the Moon Dog and Ms Vivian rolls.  It was good but let me tell you about a few red flags we saw tonight.

Apparently they made an incorrect order of hamachi nigiri because we saw a plate sitting on the sushi bar counter for over 5 mins. The sushi chef realized his mistake and took it off the counter and continued to reuse the fish to make ours!  If you've ever seen Top Chef you know that Gordon Ramsey would flip out!!!  You DONKEY!!  But we figured that it wasn't out for thaaat long so we didn't say anything.  The pieces were kinda warmer than we would have liked and the maguro wasn't cut around the ligaments and was stringy.  We also noticed that the refrigerated door for the fish was frosted so we couldn't see what the sushi chefs were doing.  What are they hiding back there anyways?

The rolls were definitely NOT as good as the first time.  Maybe they were having an off night.  We wouldn't know; this was our 2nd time eating here.  After paying the bill, my BF watched one of the woman behind the counter make a roll topped with raw salmon.  She reached into a tupperware container filler with what looked like left over salmon pieces and proceeded to top this roll.  This container was sitting out on the counter the whole time we were there.  This was not kept in the refrigerated area with the other raw items.  

I don't know if the incidents we witnessed tonight are "normal" in the restaurant business.  I think if I were a restaurant owner I would at least want my staff to recognize these are things to NOT do in front of customers.  We won't be coming here again.  The waitstaff was friendly but the food didn't meet the standards they set for themselves the first time around.  I expected higher standards from a restaurant that received such high Yelp reviews.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
We wondered in to Ariake while walking around the neighborhood last night and were very impressed with the quality of the food.  In somewhat typical SF sushi tradition, this is an establishment where the "book" is much better than it's "cover."

The salmons both regular and the Scottish special were excellent, as was the toro and red sea bream.

We had two rolls which were also very good although one of them had a "special sauce" that was a bit too "rich" and we wiped off the roll.

In short, Ariake is worth the trip.  Note that we spend over $100 for 2 of us (including 2 beers - Koshihikari Echigo which is excellent and not that easy to find) so it's not the cheapest place in town, however.
author: David A.

description:
Went there to grab a quick lunch.  Everything was good.  Nothing extremely spectacular that would make me go head over heels with this place but you cannot fully judge the restaurant by one lunch.

What you can see though is the cleanness of the bathrooms, tables and utensils, attention from the staff (although I was the only one there, so all attention went to me), and timely manner of service.  Prices are a little too high for a city full of sushi joints, but the quality is decent.

Will come there again, if I remember where it's at.
author: S C.

description: Fun small neighborhood sushi spot. Fresh and very clean. Super personal service and an at home fee. Chefs Sam and Young are super nice and friendly. Beware it can get pricy if you are hungry. Also the waitress didn't do much. She didn't even bring us water or offer us refills.
author: Yosof R.

description: A great culinary experience.  The extra fresh fishes were melting in our mouth with a colorful explosion of flavors. Plates were of good size to feed us all and let us with the nice round belly that you like to feel after a good lunch. I definitely recommend it.
author: Cyril T.

description:
A solid 4 star sushi joint. After moving to London, when I came back to SF, I was DYING for some sushi-- too $$$ in London, (or rather, £££) which is more like $$$$ with the exchange rate...

The great thing about Arikake that they are open Mondays, which seems to be the collective off day for every other sushi place in the area. 

Rolls/nigiri devoured:

-Arikake roll (spicy tuna w. seaweed salad)
-49er roll (their take on Ebisu's roll... lemon, salmon, tobiko)
-hamachi
-tomago
-halibut (I forget the japanese word)
-Spicy piku? (spicy scallop roll)

My favorites were the hamachi, arikake, and 49er roll, though I like Ebisu's version better.
author: Katie B.

description: Stumbled upon this place after finding out Lou's was closed for the holiday. Ordered the Beef Teriyaki and Tuna Chirashi and both were really good. The fish tasted fresh and the meat quality wasn't cheap at all. Ordered "to-go" and I was on my way in about 10 minutes. Would definitely come back and sit at the sushi bar if I had more time to try their other fish.
author: Russell U.

description:
Rarely do I give any place a 5-star rating. I really only eat nigiri sushi because that is the true test of a real sushi chefs sushi skill set... the rice that goes into the sushi. Most folks think it's the freshness of the fish or all the crazy sauce and other crap that goes into the jive ass rolls aka dragon and rock in this that roll. Yes freshness of the fish definitely counts but if the rice is not well seasoned and prepared then no matter how fresh your fish is its just no good. We did not have super high hopes for this place but considering on a Tuesday night at 830 there was a line out the door we were pleasantly surprised. We waited about 30 minutes and finally got a seat for two at the sushi bar and sushi chef jim served us. Unlike most pretentious stuck up Japanese sushi chefs jim was actually very friendly to his customers said hello and thank you and was overall very pleasant and fun 

We ordered uni nigiri, Hotate, ikura, kohada, moon dog roll: seared hamachi with tobiko, shrimp. miso soup, + comp edamame.

Uni was a highlight of the meal...overflowing with  creamy pillowy and very generous portion of uni...$9.00  
Ikura was good as well but salty.. it was delicious as usual but at nine dollars was a bit pricey considering other places we generally paid between 6 and $7.00

As mentioned we do not get the rolls with the crazy sauce is but the other table got the moon dog roll and it just looks scrumptious. The role is not filled with tons of imitation crab and no fish like many of the other Chinese own places but lots of fish with good fish to rice ratio and ingredients. The crunchiness of tobiko added a nice crunch and flavor to it which was nice. I'd get this roll again even though I'm generally not a big fan of rolls. Overall a new favorite sushi joint for me considering sushi chefs are 100 percent Japanese, service was good food is good and price is worth it. Yay!
author: Petri Y.

description: Not open as advertised (3pm). They say it is Yelp's fault, yet they have not contacted Yelp to fix the problem.  Either way, a let down and waste of time driving here.
author: Jeff C.

description: Fish was fresh, preparation was good, service was way distracted. Noticing we didn't get tea upon arrival, I requested it with our food order. No tea. Halfway through the meal, I stood up and accosted a waitress with the request. Still. No. Tea.
author: Nick C.

description:
We stopped by Ariake for dinner around 8:30 PM and were lucky to grab one of their last tables. This place is tiny which I loved and had a cozy vibe. 

All the ladies ordered Sapporo and we started with their seaweed salad which was cool and fresh. The rolls we split included the cherry blossom ($12.00), fire cracker ($7.00), dragon ($12.00), spider ($9.00) and one more other roll I couldn't remember and they were all decent. 

I wasn't wowed but enjoyed the good company I had and atmosphere more than anything. For a sushi place their prices are fairly decent but their rolls are also much smaller.
author: Ariza S.

description: I admit I'm a bit of a sushi snob, so when I hear of a great sushi place that I must try, I try it! And I attest to the greatness of Ariake! When I closed my eyes, I could almost pretend I was at Tsukiji market in Tokyo. The live scallop melts in your mouth and the the tako nigiri was super fresh. We also got a couple other rolls, all of which were very good, as well as the grilled squid. I've had better grilled squid, but it was pretty good here. I can't wait to go back to try some other seasonal specials!
author: Amy B.

description:
There's something about tobiko that makes me crave for it. The crunchiness of the tobiko as it pops with flavor is weirdly entertaining. 

With that being said, if you love tobiko, get the Hamachi Mango Roll. The tri-colored tobiko was soooo good. Spicy flavored goodness. 

The miso-marinated black cod and uni nigiri were great picks, too. Unfortunately, after I ordered the Hamachi Mango Roll, I wanted more tobiko but their tobiko nigiri was fishy and rubbery.

Next up, Moon Dog!
author: Tina T.

description:
I was finally able to come here for food and I was severely disappointed.  I do not know if I came in a bad day, however, for a reputable Japanese restaurant, the food was simply not acceptable.  When I came in, the restaurant was crowded however, a sweet waitress was able to fit us in a small table in the back, right by the kitchen.  Unfortunately, the smell of disinfect and soap permeated in the air, caught by my ultra sharp senses.  Btw, upon walking in, there was this prick berating one of the waitresses because he did not receive his shrimp tempura.  With his little daughter in tow, he still was able to act like a complete doosh in front of her, asking the waitress condescending things like if she spoke english.  The chef should have pulled out his hanzo blade and taught him a lesson.  

Seated in the back, the place was so busy that the waitress forgot to give us a menu.  When I motioned the gf to get us some, the waitress snapped to attention, apologizing profusely.  She was literally so sweet that if there was a Yelp for waiting service, she'd get the maximum amount of stars.  Alas, there is not.  We ordered the agadashi tofu, lion king, sashimi assortment and an order of toro.  I really love tofu and the agadashi came piping hot.  The sauce that accompanied it was so good.  It reminded me of the house special tofu in Carmel and its accompanying sauce that I have put on a pedestal.  The tofu was very good, however, it is such an easy dish that's its pretty much the same everywhere.  The sashimi came next and instead of the traditional flat cut, it was cut more into cube pieces.  The salmon did not taste very good.  Usually, good sashimi melts in your melt.  Pls. view Sushi Ran or Akoni for more details.  The salmon was tough  and tasted similar to sake that I can get at Davis Sushi Buffet or Fujis.  The hamachi was equally tough however the maguro was good.  HOWEVER, GET THIS....THE TORO WAS SO BAD.  Toro is on the more expensive end of sashimi and because it is fatty tuna, literally melts in your mouth.  You barely need to chew.  However, the toro we got had ligaments and just did not seem like good quality.  The redeeming quality was the lion king, which was very good.  Many have attempted the lion yet it has rarely been duplicated.  Most places' lion kings just crumble when you touch it with chop sticks.  It is ironic that an americanized roll is the stand out dish in a traditional sushi restaurant when it should be the quality of the fish.  

I had really high hopes for this restaurant, hoping it could by my SF Akoni or Sushi Ran, however, it really disappointed me.  However, I must say the waitresses are very sweet and I hope they can be employed by the restaurants I mentioned in the first sentence.  They forgot our toro order so gave us a third piece free of charge.
author: Brian V.

description:
Although this is my first yelp review don't be fooled.  After 5 years with my lady what else can you do besides grub to get outta the house on a regular basis? I don't consider myself a pretentious sushi snob or anything, but I do like to eat good. With that said, I've eaten at  most any Sushi places my little heart desires and there are great ones around, especially considering we live in SF. In my opinion (obviously) Ariake is the best.

Now onto the things I won't go to Ariake without ordering.

Moon Dog roll- prob one of the best rolls ive ever had. Yes it's that good.
Godzilla roll- deep fried yellowtail roll 
Albacore tataki- to die for
Hamachi Kama and Ike-jime Tai- Im sure I will ultimately regret even suggesting these items as they're only available in very limited quantities. So limited, I typically will call ahead simply to inquire whether it's even still available that day. I sincerely hope I'm not shooting myself In the foot with this one. The worst is when you order these only to be told they're sold out, then to realize your neighbor at the bar is your worst enemy because they got the last order (I'm sorry I'm still butthurt  over this)

Your not gonna have the nightclub ambiance here like other "supposed" great places. However, what you will have is a delectable dining experience that won't  leave you unable to pay your rent. Chef Jin is always eager to welcome you into his humble eating establishment with a smile and even more eager to recommend what's the best of what he has to offer. Because of this I've become a regular here even despite the fact that I live only a few blocks from Ebisu (which isn't a bad place but nowhere near Ariake' s caliber)  I've even been known to show up more than once a week depending on how bad my withdrawals are.
Yes I order plenty of other things and they're all up to par. However I'm not gonna BS you, I'd be here all day if I reviewed them all....................... and I could be at Ariake instead.
author: Cesar H.

description:
We ordered both "cooked" items (tonkatsu, beef teriyaki) as well as sashimi and rolls. In a nutshell: AVOID the cooked items altogether and focus on the raw fish.

The tonkatsu was gristly, fatty, and chewy....absolutely inedible. I left the entire thing on my plate. The beef teriyaki was also very fatty but we could at least masticate it to the point where we could swallow it. 

By contrast, the uni and ikura we ordered were absolutely fresh and delicious. If we come back, it'll be specifically for the sushi. Service was responsive and courteous.
author: SfMom O.

description: Never been disappointed. Sashimi is delicious and fresh. You have to try the moon dog roll. Really nice staff. A little pricey but what quality sushi place isn't?
author: Gabriela A.

description:
Two words: MOON DOG.

Did I ever think I would put those two words together? No.
Did I ever think I would eat something with such a name? No.
Will I sucker punch you for moon dog? YES.

After eating this, I know why this shrimp tempura roll with crab and seared ahi tuna is called moon dog. It sends your taste buds to the moon and leave you begging for more like a dog. Man, I'm so lame, but I speak the truth! Everything we had was amazingly fresh and the chef/owner is very friendly. Rolls range from $6-$12, most of the good ones are $12. ;)

P.S. I won't sucker punch you if you bring me with you to eat moon dog.
author: Dolores L.

description:
Stunning.
Get the damn Toro you cheap ba$%#$d. You only live once. Sit at the bar. Always get the specials, ALWAYS ask for "off menu" recos. And yes drink some Sake too. DUH!

Seriously, the more I spend here the better it gets.
author: Patrick S.

description:
We love sushi!

We were greeted by the nice Japanese man who makes the sushi.

We ordered 3 orders of crab sushi and an order of shrimp sushi - all this just for my son.

I got the Bob's roll, Dynamite and 49er.  I know, I always get excited, I don't even realize it's just me eating.  But hey, I almost finished them all.

I paid $62 for the meal.  A little excessive but I left the place happy and satisfied.
author: Pam S.

description: Restaurant did not honor reservation. Made a reservation for 5 people for 7pm. When our party arrived, we were told by the waitress that they could not verify the phone number on the reservation. What? If employees are incompetent enough that they can't even write down the correct phone number, then they don't deserve my business.
author: Danny J.

description: Good, but not wow. What sushi place don't have any hot sauce?! Well this one doesn't.
author: Saniya M.

description: I just learned from some of these other reviewers here that this restaurant is Korean owned. We drove around all over the richmond having trouble finding a Japanese restaurant open on a Monday until we came across Ariake. We had a nice experience sitting at the sushi bar being served by who I assume is Jin, nice man. The assorted sashimi we ordered was fresh and delicious. Salmon my favorite, was really good here. We decided to order their blue fin tuna which is their special. It was like regular tuna but cut thin and so tender it just falls apart in your mouth. Wow I wanted seconds. $5 a piece but so worth it. I want to come back for chirashi.
author: Helen L.

description:
Walking up to Ariake on Friday at 1 pm, the neon "open" sign in the window was off, causing some worry that the place was closed but sure enough, there were patrons inside.  The restaurant is nothing more than the sushi bar with a couple of tables, run by a husband/wife team where the husband is the waiter and the wife runs the kitchen.  Service was rather efficient even though there was only one waiter.

I ordered the Dragon, Mango Hamachi and Godzilla (fried yellowtail roll) All were perfectly acceptable rolls, unique in concept but nothing mind-blowing in taste or flavor.  Prices are reasonable and this is a perfectly ok sushi spot but not one I will be coming back to.
author: Brian C.

description:
I'm just honestly confused with how I ended up with my not so nice experience here.

I've read the review about this place and I've been trying to try this place out (because of the the reviews) but my horrible timing left me waiting for about two weeks. Seems like when ever I want to eat something it magically happens to be at the same random 2 hours that the place is closed. On that note I still don't understand the whole being open for 2 and a half hours then closing for 2 and a half hours just to reopen. 
Any way, I went in and asked how long my order would take before I place the order (to go order) as I had to be back at work soon. The waiter/host told me it wouldn't take long at all and so I took him at his word and place my order to go.
After waiting and waiting I get my food, I ended up with a few minutes to spare. The sushi chefs just took so long as they were talking to other customers over the bar that the waiter had to ask them multiple times where my food was. My food took so long (i couldn't give you a specific time frame as I didn't time it) that my poor waiter looked upset with the chefs when they gave him my prepared food order.

Now to the food.
I got about 3 different rolls and all 3 were horrible. The fish didn't have the flavor it's supposed to have and one of the rolls had a chunk in it. I don't know if that chunk was a fish bone or just a random hard chunk but either way if I wanted to find random hard uneatable chunk in my food I'd go get McDonalds.

For the quality of food and horrible wait that I had here I found the place to be over rated and over priced. This might have just been one of the most expensive sushi spots considering what I got in comparison to the same rolls at other sushi spots.
author: Cescilia A.

description: Expensive and you are getting gouged for standard non-sushi items.  Quality is excellent but be prepared to pay a lot.  There are better value alternatives.  Rolls and fried food shouldn't cost so much. I give them props for their standard of excellence on SFDPH:http://dph-extranet2.sfdph.org:7777/pls/eeop_htmldb/f?p=132:1:7103381575079481
author: Yohdaddy M.

description:
This is probably my favorite sushi place to go to in San Francisco so far.  There have so many selections for sushi!  Their fish taste fresh and their plates look appetizing rather than a bunch of stuff thrown on a plate.  I always get the sushi so I'm not sure about the entrees or bento boxes...but the tempura is a safe bet.

The only problem is its far away from where I live and work...
author: Nikkie P.

description:
I waited until I visited Ariake twice before I wrote a review.  A and I both decided we wanted sushi this past Saturday night, so decided to walk over to Ariake.  Sure, it was game 4 of the world series, but we were hungry.  At least I was.

We walked in a little after 5pm and it was completely empty, but they were showing the game on their flat screen tv next to the sushi bar.  Guess we weren't going to miss the game after all.

We decided to get the tataki salad, moondog roll, and split the Hope sushi dinner.  They have a small and large size for the tataki salad.  We went with the small, but it was still quite large for the two of us to share.  It was very good though.  Very fresh and delicious.  The moondog roll has quickly become one of my favorites.  It's really flavorful.  And all of the fish are so fresh!

I'll definitely come back when I'm in the mood for sushi.
author: Kris L.

description:
Yum.  Seriously yum.  Found this place looking for something that was open a bit later.  Saw the reviews on Yelp.  Once again, Dear Yelp, you have not steered me wrong.  So good.

We've been there several times now and I have to say that their fish has been very, very fresh each time we have gone.  And their rolls - OMG!!!  Of course there's the "Moon Dog", not to mention the "Ariake" and "Dragon" which play sensuous games on your palate.  But then there are the less usual dishes, like the monk fish liver (which is like fish foie gras) - as well as the Hamachi cheek (which is pretty much half a grilled Hamachi jaw).  It is seriously a little piece of Heaven on a plate.

But, if you are lucky enough, sit at the sushi bar where the real entertainment is.  Sometimes the owner and his other chef resemble the timing of Abbott and Costello with the witty banter being volleyed back and forth for the benefit of all those in ear shot.  Moreover, if you sit at the bar and ask the chef what is fresh (which most things are), you may be lucky enough to receive an impromptu "chef's selection".  

Now, the price is something that may keep it from being a weekly visit, but when we are feeling a little luxurious and in the mood for fresh, great fish, we know where to head...
author: Stephanie C.

description: I love their sea urchin sushi.  It's called the uni..  I love the sweet gooeyness in the mouth feel.   I wish we also tried the Ariake roll,  We chose the lemon avocado salmon roll, but I think the Ariake roll would have had a more distinct flavor.
author: Jackie C.

description: Food was fine. Staff was cold and not very welcoming. However, worst part was the cavalier approach they had to spending my money. It was expensive! And totally non-transparent as to what anything cost. The bill was at least 30% more than comparable meals I have at other sushi restaurants. Hey, I work hard for my money!
author: Martin K.

description:
Real sushi. My girlfriend took me here for lunch and catching up before I drove back home for work. Sushi catch up is kind of our thing and this place was such a great experience, it even compares to our former usual place in Tustin when we both used to live in Orange County.

The owner and chef were so courteous, hospitable, and helpful and their food was amazing!

Kumamoto oysters for appetizers with a kick of spice and some lovely toppings. Usually I gush over oysters because I'm a big oyster fan but the sushi is what took the spotlight here:

We both started with hamachi, I had it sashimi style and it was melt in your mouth delicious!

Next up salmon nigiri - Oh My Gosh, buttery yummy salmon with perfect sushi rice slapped down on your wooden plate and fantastically yummy!

I held myself back from ordering more to avoid feeling gluttonous and decided to try something different. The left side of the wall behind the sushi bar is fish from Japan so I asked the chef and owner for their advice. Of course toro was a definite and the owner chose another for me...

I honestly cannot remember the name of the specific fish but it doesn't matter, it was just okay. It was melty, but with such a different taste I can't compare it to any other type of sushi I've tried.

Finally, the toro. Oh the toro. This made my weekend! Perfectly marbled, and so succulently delicious, I wanted it to just stay in my mouth (that's what she said!) When I put this in my mouth everything else faded and all my senses focused on the creamy buttery deliciousness that my senses were slowly absorbing. I offered a piece to my girlfriend and when she went to cut off a piece with her chopstick, my subconscious selfishness made me flinch internally lol! 

Sharing is caring, just tell yourself that if you find yourself in the same situation. I'm working on re-educating myself so I can share my toro with no resistance next time =) She did bring me here, come on!
author: Melissa D.

description:
I personally don't like eatting sushi at all... But this place got me eatting and eatting for the longest time... Hey, If i liked! You would probably too.

I recommend more people dining in this small restaurant because you get to try out all the different sushi they have. 

Lion King.
Miss Vivian.
Moon Dog.

Alot more that i cant remember....


The place wise is pretty cramped. This place is extremely small....

You can fit about 25 people max.....


I'm not so sure about the dinner sets, but for sushi this is the place to go.


Price: $-$$

Expect about 8-11 dollars a roll. 

Recommendation: Party of 6 for 6 different types of sushi. Share?!

Don't get any plain rolls!
author: Ernest S.

description: friendly service and great lighting. loved my veggie rolls :)
author: Jane R.

description: This little restaurant is a gem!  Fresh fish, delicious and creative rolls, friendly service, and they are open until midnight on Fridays and Saturdays!   We had the "Love" Chirashi (assorted sashimi over sushi rice) and the Moon Dog Roll and the Hamachi Mango Roll.  The "Love" Chirashi had tuna, yellowtail, salmon, scallop, eel, salmon roe, sea urchin, white tuna.  For $20.95, that fabulous assortment of fish is a bargain.
author: Beth K.

description: I can't believe I hadn't heard of this place before! My friend took me here & I enjoyed it a lot. The Hamachi Mango roll was uniquely good. The uni was fresh which is always a plus. The only reason why I gave it one less star is cuz if you sit at the sushi bar, the sushi chef's do not remember what you order so you have to ask them more than once for some things. But all in all, they are very nice, food is good, & cozy, traditional ambiance.
author: Alysha K.

description:
Went with the family on a weekday night and sat at the sushi bar.

Had a variety of sushi and sashimi, none was impressive.  The chef was friendly, but he was not particularly hygienic while preparing our food.

Can't pay me to go back there.
author: daphne w.

description:
Uh, Derrick... That "weird herb" was shiso leaf. It's a Japanese thing. Welcome to your first quality sushi restaurant. 

Ariake is easily one of my favorite sushi haunts, and though all of the fish is generally very high quality, I'd recommend trying some of the house specialties, like the superior tuna tataki, live scallop, firecracker, Bob roll, and definitely try the aji and shima aji, which you don't find everywhere. Great  sake selections, too. I only wish they'd improve the music played in the restaurant.
author: Tim T.

description:
We went there for a birthday dinner tonight and the food was very fresh, yummy and arrived on quickly.  The service was prompt, actually sometimes too prompt as we were not ready to place our orders a few times the waitress came around. I tried a bunch of  new things for the first time since the birthday girl ordered them.  I think the food is excellent, quantity is fair, and the price was fair. This place is great for a date but if you are hungry and short on cash, this ain't the place for you.
Happy Dining!
author: gordon g.

description: Everything is so Fresh!!! When in season their Wild Salmon is so good. It literally melts in your mouth. Every time I go, the special fishes are amazing. I will go back whenever I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
So. good.

Over the past half-decade of living in the Richmond and trolling Clement and Geary Streets for sushi, I have to say I've found "the one."

Sometimes I pick by price, by "crowdedness" or by quality of food. This place has it all. The sushi was delish. People were nice. Small and quaint but not too crowded for a Friday night.
author: Pha L.

description:
Been here a couple times and have always had good service and good food. The last time I went here it was more entertaining than usual because the sushi chef was serving up sake to the drunk people at the bar while a cop bitched and moaned about life at the table behind me. Haha. This place definitely gets its share of characters. The other times I have came it has been really calm and intimate so I guess you will just have to take a chance in coming here. 

The rolls are yummy. I've gotten the Lion Kind like twice and it is so huge and filling. Def worth trying! The spicy tuna is always a good choice. The dragon roll is one of my faves. The fish here is pretty fresh which earns this place 4 stars. -1 star for its overbaked sushi rolls. I felt there was more batter than sushi in that thing... forgot the name of the roll, but overall I will def. be returning.
author: Jackie M.

description: One of the best sushi joints in the city! Meets the needs of both sashimi and roll enthusiasts. Fish is as fresh as it gets, rolls are perfectly created and beautifully presented.  Oh and the beer! Get the house Japanese beer.
author: Michael P.

description: A party of five of us had dinner here on a recent Friday evening (thankfully we had reservations as seems most every table could only accommodate four adults comfortably).  We ordered several rolls and a sashimi platter as well as a few appetizers and udon soup.  All of the food we had was good, service was generally quite attentive, and restaurant was well kept and clean.  I think the "prices" were in line with other Japanese restaurants however I do feel that the portions here were a little on the small side by comparison.
author: Kent W.

description:
Ariake is easily my favorite sushi place in the city (for the money).  What they lose in ambiance, they double back and kill it in unbelievable quality of fish.  We went again last Friday (I've been too many times to count), and as usual we were greeted with a warm welcome by the owner/chef and with unreal fish.

The rolls I would say are above average.  But any place can make a decent roll.  What really distinguishes one place from another is when you are tasting their Sashimi/Nigiri.  I can't say enough about their quality of fish.  Try their:  Escolar, Ocean Trout, Aji, Shima Aji, Tai, Toro, Hamachi, etc, etc, etc.  The hand-written pages on the back wall is where you should focus your attention as that will have his specialty fish listed.  Now that they finally have a decent list of sake (used to have like 2 options - hot or cold!), this place cannot be beat, though don't come here looking for ambiance, come looking for fish.  Sweet, sweet fish.  

=)
author: Andrew M.

description:
I was here about a week ago, so forgive me if I forget some of the details of my delicious meal here.  Service was friendly and attentive, and the fish tasted super fresh.  LOVE that they have wild salmon here, as I try not to eat the farmed stuff anymore and miss my sake nigiri.

I introduced my friend to Hamachi Kama, which was very good here.  A great addition to our meal!  A seaweed salad was good, but why is it that this dish tastes/looks the same EVERYWHERE regardless of where I get it?

We ordered some spicy tuna rolls, as well as a bunch of nigiri, and I enjoyed all the food as well as the conversation (both mine with my friend as well as the couple at the sushi bar, they were interesting!).  I will definitely be back here when I want to go somewhere less of a scene and want good sushi!
author: Lindsay B.

description:
bento box lunch, sushi a la carte, tea and some miso soup.

not bad. but all too regular, and not enough for it to be memorable. I am not really a fan of raw things, so I can not judge freshness or quality. however, i am a fan of bento boxes and this place is nothing out of the ordinary. portions are.. medium, and the bento box lunches and sushi are all too regular. perhaps if i had some sake my review might be more star-spangled, but I did not so... 

ariake japanese restaurant is your typical japanese restaurant. i would say that the beef teriyaki is kinda tasty. just slightly slightly above average, so i will give it 3.5 stars + .5 stars for nice waitress and good company
author: simon k.

description: So I been once sometime in December to earlier this year so the details are a bit hazy.  So my friends and I were looking for a Japanese spot to eat, and ended up here because the place we originally wanted to go was closed or something like that.  A small little place that can fit no more than 30 people.  I was here with two friends so we were able to order a variety of rolls and dishes.  The crown jewel was the fish cheeks, toro and sashimi.  The toro had this beautiful glistening shine to it, and ordered two plates of it.  The bill was high, but well worth it.
author: A L.

description: Great sushi and good service. Lots of specials with fresh items not often available. Health score 100 - that's a comfort!
author: Roger H.

description:
Service good. Price good. Food gooooooood.
What we had:
Spicy QP roll- it was really fresh and yummy! and a lot of times when I order a spicy something roll, the spicy tends to overpower the rest of the roll, but not here. it was perfect spiciness! 
Negimachi- tasty
Firecracker- mmmm....deeeeeelish! 
Natto make- I love natto maki and it's a ritual for me to get at least one at sushi restaurants, but i think they put a little too much katsuobushi (bonito flakes) in this, and it was a tad dry. but still good enough to eat
Gyoza- had the perfect amount of crispiness and the dip was really good
Tsukimi Tororo- tried the quail egg w/grated yam and it had yummy subtle flavors

What I loved about this place was that the flavors were subtle enough that you can actually enjoy the taste of the fish in the sushi, because a lot of times at sushi restaurants they put so much other ingredients that you can't really taste the fish. I'm goin back again!
author: Emy s.

description: Amazing sushi. Hole in the wall but fresh fish!! Good and Fast service. Great recommendations, even for our 2 yr old who tried his first sashimi today - blue fin tuna (AMAZING) after having grilled black cod.
author: Nikki G.

description: Came here for lunch with the family right after I got back to CA last month and I was most impressed!  VERY fresh fish at a great price and all the rolls we had were delicious.  The ramen and tonkatsu were above average as well.  Definitely give the sushi a try here if you're in the city.
author: Eric F.

description:
Is Uni better when the sushi chef lays down tongue by tongue, the individual pieces piled high?  Or is it better when the sushi chef gives you a thick slice of uni from his pile, then places the wedge on the gunken nirigir as usual?

This place did the later.  It was very generous and the uni was good quality.  But I don't know how I feel about that.  It was a cross section of uni.  Reconstructed.  Such the opposite of deconstructed. 

The Sashimi A lunch combo contains exactly the fish described in the sushi A lunch combo.  In fact, the only thing different is the addition of shredded daikon, the rice is served in a bowl (instead of nigiri) and that's about it.  The price of everything has changed from the website.  The lunch combos all cost $13.95.  For 7 pieces of sliced fish.  And a salad and a soup.  The slices of fish appeared to multitask as well and could have easily been made into nigiri.  Except the maguro.  That was the size a large postage stamp.  

The agedashi tofu was 5 smallish pieces of tofu (1.5 inches x 1.5 inches x 0.5 inches) for $4.95.  It was served very very hot with shredded bonito on top.  It tasted ok.  I could have done without this.

I am confused by this meal because it was such a reconstructed way of doing things. The servings of sashimi were small and the prices were high.  The uni was sliced rather than the whole piece.  The taste was nice and I am very very full but it was so different from...everything.  

The price was nothing like the website: Combination A - $9.95.
The Uni was nothing like I'd ever seen.
The portion of the lunch combo was smaller than the sashimi appetizer photo on Yelp.

My world is falling apart?  I need to go back to my safe place to center myself.  I need to find that sushi mecca...
author: Christina C.

description:
Decent sushi, but that special something called "service"  wasn't up to the task.

Couple friends and I decided to break out of our usual Sunset based sushi routine and headed over to The Richmond to see if there was anything worth the trip plus the joy of finding Geary parking on a Saturday evening. We settled on Ariake after a slew of places couldn't seat us right away because boy were we hungry.

Ariake, like most sushi joints, distinguishes itself on its rolls. Different variations on tried-and-true themes. I ordered the caterpillar roll -- avocado and eel -- complete with eyes out of salmon roe on top of octopus suckers and sprouts for antenna, it was the best presented caterpillar roll I've every had the pleasure of eating. Sadly, the amount of eel was poor and the avocado dominated the dish. Worse yet, no wasabi was provided! In fact, counting all the sushi dishes order by the entire table we received only two small "dollops" of wasabi. The other diners reported their sushi was better, and the few other pieces I stole were, in fact, decent.

Food was also brought out in a very strange order, with some diners receiving their entire order before another even received their sushi (to say nothing of their main dish). We then waited nearly 15 minutes after our plates were cleared before someone thought it would be nice to give us a check, or even swing by so we could ask for a check.

The tonkatsu I ordered was overly breaded, but the dipping sauce was more than sufficiently tangy, and the miso soup really hit the spot on a cold San Francisco evening. They also offer a reasonably wide selection of cold sakes and we all enjoyed our selected bottle quite a bit (but heck if I can remember what we actually ordered).

But the truth is, between the poor service, the insufficient eel, and the over-breading, I wont' be in a rush to return... except maybe for a bowl of piping hot miso.
author: Sean K.

description: The food is amazing, the value is sublime, everyone is super friendly, and it didn't seem too crowded.  My favorite sushi place in SF right now.
author: Ty W.

description:
Consistently delicious! I've been frequenting Ariake for the past 6 years and I make a point of trying all the good sushi places in the city. (Just haven't yelped them all yet!) When I was living in Japan and came back to SF for visits, I'd still hit up Ariake for it's wonderful fresh sushi delights.

All the raving you see on here about the Moon Dog is true -- if you like rolls, order one, you won't be disappointed. If you're not a roll fan, enjoy the sashimi or nigiri. Be sure to listen to the recommendations about what's fresh!
