The head chef and owner Jin is the penultimate Korean sushi chef: highly skilled, super friendly, and charming too. If you've never been to South Korea, or known any Koreans sushi chefs who honed their skills in Japan, let me assure you that race does not matter. This Korean sushi chef rocks!

Ariake is a bit pricey -- expect to pay a premium for fresh fish. The best fish go to the higher bidders.
author: Velshin C.

description:
with so much sushi on geary in the avenues i always forget that ariake is there.

i've been a few times before, and haven't had a bad meal yet.  the fish is fresh and tasty, the prices are par, and the space is cool.

they've got a decent bar, and i love sitting at the bar slowly ordering one thing after another.
author: Ameer N.

description: Came here for lunch. Got a bento box. Small portions, left feeling hungry still.....maybe I should've gotten the rolls instead.
author: Diane L.

description:
Meh. Fresh sushi and good service but the price is not worth the admission. Me and a some friends split the Bob, moondog, ariake, live scallops, and the ankimo. I also tried some of my friend's tempura udon. 

The food was nice and fresh and my favorite part of the meal was the flavorful monkfish liver. But the same food can be had at any other decent Japanese restaurant. Here it was a bit pricey for it's quality.

The staff was nice and attentive(small restaurant), I reccomend the Moon Dog and Ankimo.
author: Colin H.

description: A solid 4.5 stars!  Really fresh fish, great neighborhood find.  I found that the price was great for the level of food, although the service was lacking.  The place is tiny, so come early or on a week night.  The best thing was the Tataki and anything with raw salmon.
author: michelle l.

description:
Best sushi in San Francisco...although very very pricey.

The Moondog Roll is awesome and the 49er roll is refreshing and light.  The Toro Uni is killer!
author: David H.

description:
Amazing experience for my first time at Ariake! I've lived in the neighborhood for a year and have tried a handful of sushi spots in the Inner Richmond, and by far Ariake offers the freshest sushi and friendly, attentive service mixed with reasonable prices. 

Three of us came in at 6:00 pm on a Thursday night -- hardly rush hour. Within 15 minutes, though, nearly the "entire" restaurant (maybe 10 tables and a sushi bar) was packed, which we took to mean that we made the right choice. The staff checked in with us every few minutes, though, so service was consistently top notch throughout the meal.

Every roll was delicious; we split one each of the Bob's Roll (best one for sure -- prawn tempura topped w/seared bonito & special sauce), Dragon Roll (standard eel/avocado -- but very fresh avocado made it stand out), Dynamite Roll (spicy yellowtail, salmon and tuna deep friend w/sauce -- yum) and Godzilla (fried yellowtail -- so so) roll. The nigiri rolls were especially good -- we recommend the white tuna and the salmon. Definitely could be a good quick date spot, or for a group of friends.

And extra thanks for the extra effort on the part of the hostess -- I left my debit card behind, and she sprinted a block to catch up with us and reunite me with my one and only source of $$. A very fun night, thanks Ariake!
author: Rob N.

description: Rolls are exceptional. Rice is cooked perfectly. Delicious.  Great neighborhood find.
author: Nan W.

description:
Disappoint dinner~ 
we ordered a cherry blossom roll, which is their signature roll on the menu.
the salmon which inside the roll was too chewy , and the roll was is easy to break in parts before you put in mouth.
Deep fried soft shell crab:   too fishy and do not have crab taste.
Tempura:  very good!!  5 stars
Over all their price is expensive !!
May be not back there again....
author: SteveMorris M.

description: Nice place, very nice staff. Sushi was pretty good. Wasabi was excellent.
author: Tim M.

description:
Love this restaurant. 

 I have been coming consistently for over 10 years (yes, 10). I am hardly a 'regular' , visiting maybe 4-5 times per year.  But the food has always been outstanding and the service friendly and casual. Order anything - I have yet to be disappointed.  I agree with some of the other reviews that the prices have creeped up , but they are not by any means expensive for good sushi.  I have eaten at Kabuto just down the street many times and while that food is also outstanding (more creative than Ariake), it is also MUCH more expensive.

 I will keep Ariake as my frequent sushi restaurant and Kabuto as my 'once in a while' place to experiment.
author: Steve B.

description:
Great food and fast service. The hosts are always great and they probably have th BEST miso soup i have ever tasted. It is a bit expensive but you definitely get what you pay for. 
My friends go all the time and never have one complaint. 
Great place for a date too. :)
author: Lana K.

description:
This place own by Korean, kitchen and waitress are Korean but Japanese Sushi Chef.
This chef was good but there was something wrong goin' on, seriously.
He was such a bad mood, pissed off,  constipation, mid age crisis, menopause or having a period of guy version, etc..
I don't know.
I don't know what the fxxx was goin' on.

I was in the neighborhood for hair cut at Ricks'.
So, I just walked in for a nice lunch, it was a nice Saturday afternoon. 
There were about half full, chef was working hard, non stop.
I wasn't in a hurry so I was lookin' around.
But this chef never smiled until he asked me and  found out I am Japanese.
He started to talk to me, in Japanese, and began to bitching about his customers, out loud, in Japanese, with smile.
He was just laughing at out loud about his customer how rude they are.
I was like,
"?!?!?".
Frankly, I found he was a hella funny in the very negative way.
We all do and very funny sometimes, insult the others as a joke in some degrees.
But insult the other people, there is a line you just shouldn't step over.
And he was on the border line.

But I think I know where the come from. 
He might be a just frustrating guy who is miss communicating with his boss, co-workers and customers.

But talking about the lack of understanding of mixed culture in SF.
How authentic he wants?
How does he like to be Authentic sushi chef?
Do I want to pay a lot to get Authentic sushi?
Don't I mind to pay more for French but Japanese?
How about Chinese?

I think it's all for "Satisfaction".
If I satisfied, include food, service, people, parking, presentations,bathroom, etc, in any different way, I'll give you 5.

I wasn't so comfortable hearing bad-mouthing his custmer's "Rude" table manner. 
It was very funny in the begining but in some point, I got very tied.
I don't know who is really "rude" in his story.
I don't think I like to take my friends to come here.

It's too bad, really, because 2 reasons:
1, This Owner gets good fresh fish.
2, This Chef has good technique.
author: Nobu K.

description:
Great sushi spot.  Small place.

My favorite rolls in preferential order are:  
(1) Ms. Vivian 
(2) Hamachi Mango
(3) 49er

They also do a nice job with their tempuras.

The owners are very nice and attentive.
author: Derek N.

description:
Sometimes you have to put your foot down. Sometimes you have to realize it is someone else's birthday (happy birthday again, Stanley!) and try not to put your foot in your mouth. Sometimes you have to go with the flow. 

I am democratic when I want to be, so I gave up my want for the place I hadn't tried up the street, which is supposed to have really good sushi, to go somewhere at the request of more spicy this and creative that and deep fried the other. 

I sucked it up and tried to go back to the frou frou sushi. I mean, hell, after 7 months of unemployment I was able to go back to well gin without too much pain and suffering. How hard could it be to apply this philosophy to a funky roll that has teiyaki sauce, deep-fried crab and eel abed a plate of spicy mayo? 

Hard. Very hard. They do have fresh fish, a clean place and efficient service, but mango does not belong in a sushi roll with spicy hamachi. I am so damaged by the thought of that one that I might have to go back to the expensive gin, and just when I was getting used to the cheap stuff.
author: Drue C.

description: Saw the 4 star review so we were excited to go to Ariake. The food tasted good but the portions were super skimpy.  Paper thin pieces of fish and the "chef's choice" was 6 small and underwhelming selections, one of which was Ebi. Super weak. The bill for 2 rolls, the chef's special, and a glass of wine was $53, without tip. I'd say save your money and go somewhere else of sushi.
author: Keith O.

description:
Most of the food I tried is typical and fresh.
But
the Firecraker Roll and Toro are to die for.
mmmm ... spicy crunchy ... buttery melty... heaven.
author: Yeeman N.

description:
Ariake is great. Great as in sweaty, loud, no holds barred breakup sex. Yeah it's that good.

I went with a friend on a Saturday night. It was busy but there was almost no wait. This venue ranks high on the "places to take a date to impress her" list. Japanese food always shows a bit of culture, eh?

Anyway, the only true comment I can make is the toro. The toro is like rough breakup sex with a bit of spanking.  It was like a slice of heaven with the tuna literally melting in your mouth. Check it out...you won't be disappointed.
author: Jeff T.

description:
disappointing place for sushi. if you like rolls then maybe this is your type of joint. 

i think of all the dishes that we ordered, i liked the ariake roll (spicy tuna roll with wakame salad on top) and the hamachi kama (broiled yellowtail shoulder) appetizer. 

But trust me, I've had WAY better sushi and cooked dishes before so given the price (the bill ended up being $36/person) i would not recommend this place.

Oh and the service was completely off. And if you are not a fan of imitation crab, beware that most of the rolls with fried tempura use fake crab. Yuck.
author: Helen Y.

description: Officially my favorite sushi place in the bay.  Nice variety of standard and specialty rolls.  I like how they use lemon on some of the rolls.  Also, the firecracker is awesome.
author: Vanessa S.

description:
Who knew???

I have lived in Richmond most if not all of my life.  This place has surpassed my frame of vision for sometime now.  All is not lost.  My little brother took the mom and I here for our birthday.  While she - stuck in her ways stuck to tempura and rice, sometimes venturing over to the sashimi we were having, my brother and I went for all things still alive and kicking.  Their oyster was delicious - small compared to Sushi Tani, but still fresh and refreshing.  My assorted sashimi of tuna, sake and hamachi were fresh and also refreshing, again quite small.  At this point...still quite hungry.  The rolls on the other hand were of good size.  I have to say I left kinda hungry.  I just couldn't justify ordering more though...

But next time, I'll have to try the uni...it'll make or break the place for me....
author: Julie H.

description:
Love the fresh fish.  A little bit on the pricey side, but the rolls are definitely good.  I came here for a friend's birthday and as we sat down and looked at the menu the waitress, I noticed on the nice white board menu behind the sushi chefs that they had TORO and UNI.  I was immediately fiending it and put an order in.  (later in the night, i ordered one more of the toro too).  I also had the Hidden Treasure which was like a chef special.

At first it was a a little dissapointing for the price of $12.95 with a almost seafood salad type dish with various sashimi.  However, it was still relatively good.  Luckily, we were doing family style, so I got the chance to try out the Island, Rainbow, and several other ones.  


It's always great to have lotsa sushi, lotsa company, and lots n lotsa beer n saki.  Good times.
author: Vincent K.

description:
For those allergic to seafood but love Japanese cuisine.

It's taking a while but I'm working on compiling a list of Japanese restaurants in the Bay Area that serve a broad selection of flavorful non-seafood dishes.

Here's what I have so far: 

1. Oyagi - San Francisco
2. Tokie's - Foster City
3. Kitaro - San Francisco (fast food like for me but reliable)
4. Ariake - San Francisco
5.
6.
up to 10.

As you can see, I'm looking to build a top ten list but it has become a surprisingly challenging task as most restaurants I find specialize in sushi.  

Anyway ,thanks Yelp for your suggestions so far. I'll keep you up to date on my progress.

Quick Synopsis - Friendly Vibe. Attentive Service. Gregarious sushi chef. 
Decent :agedashi tofu, yakitori,chicken teriyaki. Clean. Reasonable Prices. Sushi -Good (confirmed by dan b.)
author: Stella B.

description:
Visited Ariake for dinner last night with my hubby.  We went in around 6pm and there were only 2 other parties there but it filled up pretty quickly as we were having dinner.  They were nice enough to turn on the heater right above our table as it was a chilly evening.

Our little table in the corner was nicely decorated with a fresh red rose.  A pretty nice touch.  The service was excellent and very efficient.  An empty dish never stayed on our table for more than a few minutes before being whisked away.

We ordered the "Love" chirashi, monk fish liver, and chicken teriyaki.  They were nice enough to substitute the salmon roe for extra hamachi, my fav fish, in the chirashi.  The sashimi in the chirashi was excellent, very fresh, and I enjoyed the other ingredients of the dish, the marinated bamboo (I think), the soy sauce mushrooms, the sprouts, shredded turnip, and tamago.  For $20, I was very satisfied.  The monk fish liver was nicely sauced, a bit soy and spicy sauce. Yum!  If you like liver pate, you'd like this dish.  The chicken teriyaki wasn't terribly special but a good portion and tasted like chicken teriyaki should taste, not over-sweetened like some places.

Overall, a good dining experience.  Oh, their tea smells (and tastes!) so delicious after coming in from the cold!  Our dinner cost about $50 after already adding tip.  Pretty affordable considering how much sashimi I ended up eating.
author: Jenn T.

description:
the nicest nicest lady waittress works here.  always around when u need her.
interior was small, soothing, comfortable.
food was above average, delicious.
the cherry blossom roll was beautiful.
clean bathroom.

tremendous homey feel, i like that a lot...
author: Ethan L.

description:
There ain't much outstanding here. Yeah, it's sushi. Just like the sushi in the five million other moderately-priced sushi joints on Geary in the Middle Richmond.

Oh, okay. There are a few outstanding things about it, even if they don't really have much to do with the sushi...

There's the super friendly younger sushi chef, who gets so excited to see you when you walk through the door, or when you order his favorite "island" roll, that he smiles so big you think his face is going to melt off...

There's the fact that they're lightening-fast, even when they're packed, and when they DO screw things up, the servers come right out and apologize in a no-nonsense, "yeah, I'm an idiot, I screwed up" kinda way...

And there's the fact that it's only .35 blocks from my apartment... That's probably the best thing about it. I'm sure you'd agree...

No, wait -- the BEST thing about it is the feisty little Nisei waitress who didn't take any crap from the nastiest homeless man I have EVER seen, who charged in there on a busy Thursday night last week while I was enjoying a peaceful dinner with a friend. He had barfed in his long tangle of a beard, and literally came STORMING through the door, growling (no joke!), stinking the place up, demanding to use the bathroom. She got right in his path, and I thought he was going to smack her down. 

But she stood her ground. Instead he just sidestepped her, eventually found the bathroom, and locked himself in, leaving the staff and patrons dumbfounded. We all sort of bonded over the experience, while dude stayed locked in the bathroom, Smiley the Sushi Chef made everyone free nigiri, and Smiley's son (who was forbidden to kick smelly guy's ass) called the cops. 

I now feel something a lot stronger for Ariake.
author: Lisa T.

description:
Sometimes surprises are fun. Like guessing what's behind door number three and winning a brand new car. Unfortunately, I am not so sure that the inconsistency with the food at Ariake is a game of surprise I particularly enjoy. It's more like finding out that you still won a brand new car, but it's a 1976 Chevrolet Caprice that doesn't even have the original 8-track player so you can show it off to your hipster friends.

The food at Ariake seems to be either extremely delicious or not so great. I have yet to get a mix of the two extremes, but I have noticed that the not so great food usually occurs when they are a little busier. This also seems to affect the pacing of the food. You may get your first roll after 10 minutes and your second after 20. I also noticed that though customers sitting at the bar may come in quite awhile after me, they are served first. So I suggest thinking about another option if the place is busy or trying to sit at the bar. The service is always friendly and when the food is "On" they have one of the best Dragon rolls (which I am normally not crazy about) I have ever had.
author: J F.

description:
Ariake serves up some great sushi with excellent service.  My group of four got seated right away at around 8:00pm on a Tuesday evening...lucky as it was the last table available.  We ordered the large house sake and to be quite honest, there was nothing large about it...barely enough for 1.5 shots per person.  Decent quality for $6.00.  

The rolls we ordered were delish!  My favorite was the dragon and the Ariake roll (the wakame salad a top tuna roll).  There were a couple of rolls I didn't care too much for because they had pickled carrots.  Big fan of carrots, but pickled the way they were at Ariake, don't like AT ALL.  It's like what some folks think about cilantro...it's the most dominant taste and over powers even the most dynamic tastes (eg tempura).  

Service is awesome.  The servers are attentive with tea and water and food go to our table quickly and almost around the same time (two rolls came out and then the other two).  

Definitely will go back and try some of the fresh sashimi everyone (including my friends) are talking about.
author: Marie B.

description: Amazingly good sushi and super fresh. I wish that I knew of this place before and will definitely go again. Their rolls are simple, menu is simple, and it's like the most hidden Geary St  sushi secret. Love it!
author: Wendy A.

description:
Some of the most flavorful sushi and sashimi I have ever had. Top rate ingredients, very creative specialty rolls, and great presentation and service, as long as you're willing to be just a little proactive and ask for what you want.

I'm also very conscious of sustainable fishing, and Ariake had a good selection of great rolls (including the Ariake Roll) that was both delicious and reasonably sustainable.
author: Lekan W.

description:
The sushi is good.  Fresh fish, generous portions, nice variety.  There is also a nice selection of specials on any given night and the sushi chefs are very friendly.  

I don't eat here anymore though.  For a place that is NEVER crowded they have a really half-assed way of billing you.  I like to look over the bill before I pay...to make sure everything is right.  This is especially important at a sushi restaurant  because your order may be taken 3 or 4 times in a sitting, sometimes by different people.  Plenty of potential for mistakes.  When you get your bill at Ariake, it says, "sushi $85" or whatever the grand total is plus tax and a total at the bottom.  No itemizing.  Ever.  

Yes, it's kind of nit-picky and some would argue that it's not a good enough reason to boycott good sushi but I want to know exactly what sushi I'm paying for.
author: M M.

description:
My friend and I tried Ariake the other night, based on the reviews she read here on Yelp. It didn't disappoint. The atmosphere was lovely and very neighborhood-like and friendly. Jin was the perfect host and introduced himself and asked our names. Another couple at the sushi bar said they'd started coming to Ariake four years ago, but since moving out of the neighborhood still came back all the time with family & friends.

And not only was it friendly - it was delicious and fresh! And the portions were really large but the price tag was small. This is my new favorite sushi spot in the city! Yum!
author: Victoria S.

description:
I like.

This place gets a good review based on a few things. 

One: selection, I fear no fish and the variety here keeps me happy.  Definitely try the monk fish livers and eat up some live scallops.  

Two: The owner is super friendly and enjoys his customer's company.  This is actually a big deal to me I'll choose a place with better people than food any day.

Three: Moderate prices for good quality.  This generally is what people look for most when eating out, but as mentioned earlier not me.

Well rounded and nice people make it work here, cheers.
author: Paxton F.

description:
always good sushi. i can't eat sea food but when i eat sea food here it doesn't make me puke but i still get sick!! haha.
Very nice waiters and chefs!!
author: Timothy C.

description:
Best sushi place in the city! The fish is always fresh, and anything I tried here was a-ma-zing! It has been a must-visit-at-least-once-a-month-place for couple years already! 

My favorites: Tuna Tataki, Cliff House, Moon Dog!
author: Anastasiia G.

description:
fair price, for very decent sashimi and sushi rolls.

i wouldn't say it is the best sashimi i've had, but salmon, tuna and uni were really good. the rolls didnt have heavy sauce on them, which is always a plus.

cool atmosphere, very friendly chef and staff.
author: Danielle A.

description:
Excellent sashimi - we just asked for what was freshest and definitely weren't disappointed. The makisushi leaves a little to be desired - the rice wasn't sticky enough to hold the roll together very well, but the flavors were very good. The Firecracker plate was really good - fried shiso leaf with spicy tuna piled on top. Tough to eat daintily, but who cares when it's that tasty?

The couple next to us had udon noodles that looked - and smelled - delicious. I'll definitely be trying those next time!
author: Sarah G.

description:
I have yet to find better sushi in SF.

This place is quite small, so if you want to come here for dinner, I suggest coming early.

The staff is very nice and friendly and the sushi is delicious.

I have tried a bunch of differently rolls and I can't tell you which is my favorite.  They all are so flavorful and fresh.

If a friend wanted bomb sushi, I would take them here.
author: Jules G.

description:
Really good Japanese restaurant in the Outer Richmond and I can't believe I have not gone here more often. Went here for the first time years ago and finally tried it again today for lunch. 

The shrimp/veggies tempura is great -- not too much batter and was served with strips of tuna sashimi, side salad and rice. Salmon nigiri was delicious, fish so fresh, it melted in my mouth. The spiciness of the Dynamite Roll was perfect :-)!

Service was a bit slow, only one waitress, one sushi chef and another chef in the kitchen, but the food is worth the wait. If you sit at the bar, you get free edamame to snack on while waiting for your food.
author: Celeste M.

description:
Best. Sushi. Ever.


fat ass nigiri pieces. BUTTAH!

I've had sushi in japan and hong kong, and this place rivals some pretty top-notch spots in said locations. Granted, I was well-drunk at that point, but the experience was friggin awesome. Great service, excellent sushi, overall a great night. FRESH FISH is the deciding factor here.
author: Marty K.

description:
This may be my new favorite sushi place.  3 of us ran up about $130 worth of sushi (no alcohol) yesterday and everything was amazing.  The fish was fresh and the presentation was exceptional.  It's kind of small, but we had no problems getting a seat.  

The toro was unbelievable.  Buttery and decadent.  The dragon rolls are the best in the city.  The Cherry Blossom roll was almost as impressive to look at, as it was to eat.  The Firefighter roll, with it's super spicy tuna and habanero peppers, was probably my favorite roll.  

It could be deemed on the pricy side, but you get what you pay for.  The service is excellent, and we kept ordering additional rolls, because it was just so good.  Definite recommendation.
author: matt c.

description:
When the fiance and I are out and about w/o the kiddos, we always search for food that to us, is harder to eat w/kiddos around. Sushi is one of those meals. One, because you want to enjoy every little morsel of taste as it reaches your mouth w/o anyone swatting, screaming, or lunging at you and two, because I have a ginormous fear that I will poke above mentioned kiddos w/my chopsticks while attempting to tackle reason one. Not a pretty sight, folks.

So sushi it was and w/a dash of citysearch and a serving of yelp we stumbled across Ariake. And why yes, fellow yelpers, you are on the mark w/this one. If I were to gauge the cost of the sushi against the taste my belly and wallet would say, yay, I'm a fan and pat me on the back for being financially savvy. The Moon Doggie and Bob are my favorite. The spot is a little tight, but you really won't care b/c they are quite friendly and it makes it easier to ask the table/person next to you what they're having and what they think of it. (Now, I didn't do that but I saw a couple strangers discussing their plates and I'd like to believe it's not due to Christmas spirit.) So go, Ariake, it's yummy, I wish you luck in finding a parking space.
author: Cecile Q.

description: really slow wait staff, distracted unsatisfying service. We waited about 40 minutes for our order, though the restaurant was not busy. Shame, because the fish is quite fresh and tasty (had the dragon roll & the sushi dinner). Not sure I'll go back, seeing that the neighborhood has many other great sushi spots (Shimo is consistently good and friendly).
author: K L.

description:
Ariake has become our latest Japanese favorite in the city.  The owner (who speaks both Japanese and Korean) is very friendly, and I think he actually remembers you after you've gone there a few times.  

My hubby and I tend to order all the fatty types of fish.  Unfortunately, that also means we rack up the bill whenever we go out for quality sushi.  But your money is always well spent here at Ariake.  You leave feeling as though your mouth just finished a two-hour massage.  

The last time we went, we brought a Japanese friend who is a foody just like us.  When the meal was over, she gave the restaurant her two thumbs up.   

Don't go to Ariake unless you're willing to get only the best.  

Some highlights were the toro, the uni (piled high) - sooo incredibly nutty, the amaebi heads (better than most places we've been to!  You could taste all the yummy goods in those heads when we went in early March 2008), and the liver (appetizer)) and the agedashi tofu (let it bathe in sauce that they provide for you and you will not regret it the least)... and just try something different.  Don't be afraid to ask the owner what he recommends!

enjoy
author: Natalie T.

description:
A place to stop by if you're in the neighborhood, especially if you have some extra time to kill until your next bus at the Geary & Park Presideo intersection.

I'm just in the neighborhood but have never tried it until my sister recommended it.

Rolls - To Get?

Moon Dog - Yes

Island - Yes

Spicy Mango - Yes

Hamachi Scallop - Yes

Lion King - Yes

Good for sushi roll lovers.
author: Jimmy N.

description:
Came here last night for a quick-japanese-craving-type-bite-to-eat.  

It was already 11:15pm, so most of the places on Geary were closed.  However, after a few drives back and forth between Clement and Geary, we discovered this jewel.  It's somewhat hidden, and small.

Nobody was in there, so it made me kind of skeptical.  My parents always said watch out for the places with no customers.  It was late which was considerable but my perception of the Sunset/Richmond neighborhood is that there are always late-diners around here.  

But WHATEVER.. we just wanted to get our hands on some sushi/japanese food already!

Decided to order the dragon roll to split between the two of us.

Now I know my review is based on just one item, but that has probably got to be one of the, if not best already, BEST dragon rolls I have ever tasted.  It was extremely fresh and made with juicy goodness.  The roll came with about 10-12 pieces for $12.00.  Mmm, that was kind of pricey huh now that I think about it.. 1 dollar a pop! Dinner Bento Boxes were about something like $14.95 for two items, and $17.95 for 3.  A bit on the expensive side compared to many of the other restaurants in the area.

I also LOVED that the restaurant was owned by authentic Japanese people, not by Koreans or Chinese, haha.

Definitely could be expecting a potential revisit from me in the future.
author: Leslie Y.

description: This could be the best sushi place I've ever eaten at. The fish is fresh, tasty and well prepared. Their special rolls are awesome and the service is top notch. The only draw back is that it's a very small place and fri/sat night there is a long wait.
author: Rachel Y.

description: Randomly came here, very satisfied!  Will definitely be coming back.  Rolls were great service great fish great.  Moon dog roll is phenom.
author: Alex L.

description:
Sushi as a comfort food?  Probably not.  

BUT

Ariake definitely has that home like ambiance which imparts a comfort type feeling towards your dining experience there.  So, in a way, sushi is a comfort food.

It definitely doesn't hurt to have friendly sushi chefs and warm servers.  

The sushi is very good.  As another yelper posted, they have escolar.  I never noticed that it was so rare of a fish to offer.... it is good!

So what makes Ariake really good? 

Great atmosphere, great service, tasty sushi (and rolls - the mango roll is my favorite) and at a really good price.
author: Kenneth K.

description:
This place is pretty good BUT..there's a but...... 
Ordered take-out from here a few weeks ago. Read the reviews and ordered some of the special rolls recommended. But do yourself a favor and DO NOT order the Uni! OMG, one of my two bad experiences with Uni. I spit it back out. It was so gross. They're lucky I wasn't eating it in the restaurant. I'll order from them again but not the Uni and maybe not the sashimi (not as fresh as everyone is saying) If I don't order Uni or sashimi--what's the point of ordering Japanese? 

Hmmmm  ; / maybe it was a bad day for them? but every day should be a good day, right?
author: Kim D.

description:
Overall, Ariake has more things going for it than any other sushi joint in the Middle Richmond - extremely high quality fish, friendly sushi chefs, a nice atmosphere, and lots of exciting creations to try.

But the downside - small portions, cramped conditions, boiling hot tea, and pretty weak service.  Seriously, it was like they were auditioning waitresses and we were paying the price.  It was a busy Monday night around 7, but watching the two waitresses handling the customers was like watching a hyperactive 5th grader trying to do calculus.  We got tired of it and left...still hungry.

I'd love to try it another time, but will definitely make sure it's no more than 50% full.  Great fish, but not a dining experience I'd care to repeat anytime soon.
author: John H.

description:
Birthday dinner for my man here last night, and it was delicious!  I had udon soup and we shared a plate of sushi rolls (the Ariake).  I tried the salmon, which was very fresh, but my favorite was the california roll - absolutely delicious!!  The soup was good also - large portion and very filling.  The prices are reasonable and the food is high quality - Ariake is rated a 27/30 for food on Zagat for a reason! 
Service was also good, well-paced and our server was very sweet - she responded promptly to all of our requests and even brought us complimentary scoops of green tea ice cream in honor of the b-day.  Yum!!
author: Nicholle B.

description: Been here quite a few times now.  The service is good and the staff is very friendly.  They will always greet you when you enter!  They serve very good quality sushi.  The udon was the best udon I've had so far in S.F. Their hours are pretty good.  Late night dinners will appreciate them haha.  They usually have their TV on for sporting events.  This place is great.
author: Jesse C.

description:
yum yum yum yum... all i can say is it was delicious... yummy beyond yum yum... it was so good... I wish I can eat more and more!
I had their special the ariake roll and I had the 49er, and the oyster,although it was some tiny oyster, I commend them for good authentic japanese food... yummmmmmmmmmmmmy! Def, will come bak
author: Monika T.

description:
they precook their shrimp tempura 8 hours before it's rolled into your sushi.

they tried to charge 6 dollars to add mango to our salmon/avocado roll and ended up giving us a tuna avocado roll.

the rice was hard.

row tasted rotten.

and they were rude when we picked up our order.
author: David O.

description:
Nothing spectacular.  I tried some imported Aji and got some salmon sashimi.  I really need to hit this place a few times to give it an honest review.  I'll give it solid three for now.  They asked me some questions about other places and my opinion.  From the tone of the conversation, I guess they wanted to know the competition in the hood.  I gave them my opinion on a half dozen.  The sushi chef was familiar with some of his colleagues along the Geary strip.   The service was good.  The place looks dead alot of the times I drive by.  They have fresh sushi, they just need to do something with it that will differentiate themselves.    Alot of Korean owned sushi places taste like them.... anyways..  try it.

BTW, sounds like some of the reviews here are fake:)  Expecially the ones who claim they have the best sushi and only have one or two restaurant reviews and they give this place a 5...BS!
author: Demanding T.

description:
Late night dining at its finest. Mango roll and moon dog roll are the best. Pork tonkatsu could use a little work since it was a bit too chewy for my liking. But sake, large sapporo, rolls, and green tea ice cream really hit the spot at 11pm. 

Best friendly service by the way . Will definitely be back.
author: Eddie L.

description: My all time favorite sushi restaurant! Moon dog and tuna tataki is amazing. Yes, its not a large restaurant and you won't be getting any fancy drinks here, but if you want fresh sashimi and creative rolls, this is the place!
author: Yelena K.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE.

Moondog, yum.  Best roll, and primary reason ive been a loyal fan now for 6 years.  I drive from San Jose, just to eat great sushi here.  The maguro mango roll is really good as well, bob's is an excellent choice.  Spicy scallop hand roll is almost a must try.  One other combination that Gin will make for me is the moondog handroll, yes its not on the menu but he will make it for you.  Gin also makes the moondog extra spicy for me, you can ask him I'm a fan of spicy food.  There's also a secret "special roll", as well with thinly sliced lemon peel, imitation caviar, and white tuna.  Tataki salad is really good and you can ask for a half size if there's only two of you eating otherwise its a huge plate, firecracker is our appetizer and always delivers on good taste.  Ariake roll is good, as well.  Fresh raw scallops are really good as well, with the combination of the sauce that comes with it.  I also always ask for unagi sauce on the side to change up the flavor of not having to have just wasabi and soy sauce.

There's only one roll i advise not to try "dragon roll" its the only roll that this place does not do right.  The eel tastes burnt for some reason.

My suggestion to people is to go here when they are not as busy, i notice that the waiter staff are sometimes inexperienced.  I never have a problem with that, but notice other people do.  That is why i sit at the sushi bar.

This place delivers their fish daily at lunch time, none of it is frozen and you can tell in the taste of the fish.  I was here several times during lunch time, and you can see that they get their delivery during that time.

Gin (owner/chef) you are awesome.
author: Andrei A.

description:
This place is a little hidden gem!  I'll have to say I passed by Ariake's a million times while driving down Geary Blvd., but never made it a point to go in.  Boy am I happy my friend took me here.  The sushi was excellent!!  Everything we ordered was fresh and appetizing.  The uni, salmon, super white tuna are all ichiban!  The rolls aren't too bad either.  And nothing beats free edamame, my fav!  

Overall I had a very pleasant dining experience here.  The owner seems to have a personality and spark about him that makes people want to come back.  Although the service from the waitress' could use a little improvement, that probably won't stop me from visiting this place again in the future.  

But patrons beware... this place is quite small and it gets packed rather quickly.  My friend and I visited Ariake's on a Monday night and the place was super busy.
author: Vindy C.

description:
it was ok when i went
i went for lunch.  
got bento with CA roll and tempura.  forgot if i got a third item.  
they don't use the nasty iceberg lettuce, but i wanted sesame dressing.  
the tempura was just right.  it was light, crunchy, and hot.  i wish they had sweet potato or some other vegetables included but w/e.
it's nice that they had seaweed salad and those purple pickles.
i'm glad the bento box did not have a slice of orange.  i hate the slice of orange that most places have.  

minimum service.  the lady refilled my water once.  the sushi man is nice.  he smiles and has a friendly tone of voice.  

i wanted to take the sushi clock with me or maybe go somewhere where they will serve me pieces of sushi on a clock platter.
author: Candy Y.

description:
Just got back from a birthday dinner here and had to Yelp the hell out of it. While it was very quant and charming, there are too many great sushi spots in SF to be sub par. That's exactly what this place was. Not bad... except for the fact that the waitress brought us hamachi and tried to convince us it was white tuna (I know what white tuna is - it's white!) But overall, I wasn't really wowed by the experience.

If you go, you MUST try the sushi foie gras. I'm not even sure how you can make foie gras using sushi (I can't remember which fish it involved, but I'm leaning toward something like hamachi). None of the other rolls stood out and their roll selection was somewhat limited. 

The company was great (I love my friends), but all in all, the food itself and the service were both underwhelming. There was also a point during the night when the entire restaurant was watching American Idol playing on the screen. I can do that at home! Hit up one of the other cute joints in the area - I think there are 10 on Geary alone!

Oh and some little kid at a nearby table called me "Mommy" while we were eating. I was worried enough about turning 26 - is this an omen!??
author: Alex H.

description:
I can't say much more than what other reviews have already stated - and wholeheartedly agree. A small neighborhood joint with super fresh sashimi and a small selection of innovative (but not overstuffed) rolls....try the Bob's roll, created for and named after my old roommate's good friend (a regular obviously!) is *yummy*. Service at the sushi bar was good and better yet, they are open on Mondays (when many of the better sushi joints tend to be closed).  

Update: returned and weren't able to sit at the sushi bar. The waitresses are inept. Having waited tables in a Japanese restaurant in college, I know it can be tough to balance the inconsistent timing on food preparation between the kitchen and the sushi bar, especially when it's busy. But that's no excuse for not offering tea or water, ignoring us for 10 minutes after we've been seated, and for not checking on our sushi order until we had to ask - especially when the one person in our group had already *finished* his entire teriyaki and tempura bento from the kitchen. Inexcusable. Aside from that, the sushi still kicks booty. Just make sure you sit at the sushi bar!
author: Suepattra M.

description: Great sushi for a reasonable price. Super-fresh fish and very friendly service. Check out their list of special Japanese beer imports.
author: Wolfgang S.

description:
This is the best sushi I've had in SF and isn't as expensive as some other places people will recommend. First off, it's a fish joint and not a place that specializes in crazy American-style rolls, so they focus on the high quality and simplicity of the fish itself. Jin-Sun, the chef is a friendly guy and really knows his stuff.

My favorites are the variety of fish he carries, including Shima Aji (yellow jack), Kanpachi (amber jack), Tai (red snapper), great tuna sashimi, adn then also the live scallop that he often has - comes raw on rice and then there's a second serving course of scallop tempura with a special dipping sauce. Also a big fan of his spicy tuna hand rolls, and if you are looking to try a more modern-style roll, try the 49er Roll which is salmon with paper thin meyer lemon slices and avocado.

I'm sad to even post this review since it's a small place and I selfishly don't want it to be as busy as it should rightfully be.....
author: David W.

description:
Best deals are the sushi dinner - skip the "Kiss" or "Faith" and go directly for the "Love sushi/sashimi combo".  The restaurant probably hates me for telling you this since you will only spend $30/person instead of higher amount (for 2 people).  For me & my girlfriends, the dinner is enough to feed 3 gals, since it includes:

sashimi combo
4-5 kinds of nigiri (2 pieces each)
2 rolls (dragon & ariake rolls)
soup & salad for 2 people

Yes, the other yelpers are correct - you get the 2nd citizen look/treatment if you don't blow more money away.  It doesn't bother me much since I know I'm getting a good deal.

The service is not consistent and I'm not a regular who gets special treatment...sometimes, the waitress is good, other times, sucks...just depends on your "luck".

I notice sushi-bar people get free edamame but not the people at the table - weird.
author: Bessie T.

description:
My wife and I stopped here for lunch on our way through San Francisco on Route 1 and were pleasantly surprised by this restaurant, some of the most beautiful sushi I have seen. She ordered the wakame salad, a California roll, and a "Firecracker" while I ordered a miso soup, "Firecracker" and a "Lion King roll".

The Firecracker was listed on the "special rolls" menu, but turned out to be 4 piles of spicy tuna on top of tempora'ed shiso "crackers" with roe and additional garnishing touches. I was very impressed by both the beauty and flavor in this dish.

The Lion King roll turned out to be basically a California roll inside-out and draped in salmon and then baked. It was also beautiful and tasty, but I was expecting raw salmon rather than the roll being baked. (The special board I ordered from didn't mention this, thought the menu did.)

Over all, I would heartily recommend the Firecracker and the restaurant, but recommend avoiding the Lion King roll if you prefer your fish raw. The chef was excellent and friendly (we sat at the bar) and I was really impressed by the beauty of his presentation, it really was like eating art.
author: Adam F.

description:
Ok service, but the food was below average. I'm surprised that a restaurant like this can survive in sf. One of their rolls, the Godzilla, was so bad I had trouble finishing it. I pointed this out to the server and all she said was sorry. Not that it was a lot of money but the amount should have been subtracted from the final bill. 

Will not go back. Plenty of other sushi places around the area with better food.
author: John H.

description:
Pretty good place for sushi. Solid four stars. Fish is always fresh, service is always friendly. Great selection of specials on the board. Super good Japanese beer, I don't remember what the name of is but it is the only 8 bucks a pop Japanese beer I've tried. 

They also make Tai kama, which I haven't had anywhere else and it is quite amazing. Oh, and they are open on most major holidays, including Christmas:)
author: Andre D.

description:
Disappointed.

My friend said it was really good, and she took me there but:

Rice falls apart
Uni was funky
Surprisingly pricey for the quality
Inconsistent portions

and, bad acoustics - hard to hear.

The service was very attentive though, so not a bad time, but you can find better fish and a better place to eat it.
author: Alexander M.

description:
I went to Ariake a LONG time ago with my brother's foodie friend. She's been everywhere! I'm so glad I tagged along because I discovered a great Japanese restaurant. I went there for lunch the other day and was very happy that the quality of the food and service was still exceptional!

I had the Ms Vivien roll which was fried tempura with white tuna on top - the sushi was fresh fried tempura was warm against my tongue. The nebiyaki udon was also very good. It came in a cast iron pot and was full of fresh veggies, shrimp tempura, and chicken. My bf had the 3 item combo which was only $9.95 and the bento box was enormous. We didn't leave any food on the table and went home very happy! We will definitely be going back again for more sushi!
author: Josephine H.

description:
This is going to be a new sushi place for me whenever I have my sushi craving. We went here because we didn't want to eat something heavy for dinner. I must say that the sushi were pretty good, and the prices are decent. You get pretty good value for what you order.  Well, we are picky about our sushi after being spoiled with delicious variations of sushi in Hawaii. 

We ordered special sushi- Spider, Dynamite, Dragon, Ariake, and Island. They are surprisingly good.  The restaurant is pretty creative with what they put on their sushi, such as sauces, or lemon (yeah, lemon!!). The portions are just right, not too small or too big, and we got edamame (soybean) for free for appetizer! Sooo, I am satisfied with the sushi place and they have good sushi, friendly people with decent price of sushi!!! And, they open late on the weekend!!
author: Daisy S.

description:
Very very good sushi.  The best I have had in San Francisco since moving here 9 years ago.

Everything is fresh.  The fireman's roll and the moondog are ridiculously good.  The fireman's is basically a suped up spicy tuna roll, a bit more creamy.  The moondog has a bunch of various fish on it and is topped with a delicious sauce.  All the nigiri is tender, and the salmon melts in your mouth.

The sushi chefs are very friendly, the waitresses are ok.

Price is about average for sushi in SF.  Definitely worth it.
author: Sheila S.

description:
The Tuna Tataki here is just to die for.  

Great fish quality, reasonable prices, small and quaint.  Sushi chefs here make some incredible special rolls.

ATMOSPHERE: 4

PARKING: 4

FOOD: 5

OVERALL: 4
author: Emily H.

description: Moon Dog ... mmmmmm ... I dream of the moon dog!  The Dragon roll, Hamachi Mango and any nigiri are winners in my book.  Ariake is my new go-to for sushi.  YUM!
author: toloveisto b.

description: One of the better sushi restaurants I've been to in some stuff. And the staff rules. I shall return often.
author: K F.

description: This place is SO good. To me so much of what makes sushi delicious is the perfect texture of the rice and the optimal amount of vinegar, which this place has definitely aced. I've been on a hunt for the perfect sushi place since moving to SF, and this definitely tops the list for me (even compared to places twice as expensive). The decor and ambiance is totally humble and unassuming, but the food is out of this world.
author: Kathryn M.

description: Great sushi, although i'm beginning to think that you just can't get great tuna in San Francisco (tuna was just OK), the salmon was fantastic, especially in the 49'r roll.  Been going to Minami mostly for sushi in the area, but i think this has become a big contender now.
author: Phil J.

description:
Alright, so this has happened twice now: I've gone to Kabuto, my favorite sushi spot in the city, on a Saturday night and said "fuck this fucking line" and walked a block east to Ariake.

Whoever said being impatient wasn't a virtue?  If not for that I'd never have found Ariake.  Here's the skinny: Jin and his co-chefs are awesome, sit at the bar and buy them a beer or two, kick back and let the fish fly.

This place has really good fish.  Period.  

I think both times I've gotten out having eaten my fill of sashimi (fuck rice) with a couple beers and a bottle of saki --- 70$ per person... that sounds about right.  A little more than half the price of Kabuto and well worth it.

EDIT:
'went back again, sat at the bar and asked "what's the best piece of fish you've got?" Jin scratched his head for a second, smiled, and went backstage - returning with what was a huge 10lb cut of tuna.  Holy Crap.  With a sharp knife he went to work cutting us the best toro we'd ever seen.  I can taste it now, god damnit... I love this place!
author: Rob R.

description: As we entered, we were seated immediately by a cheerful waitress. I ordered the tempura udon and a California roll. It was good, considering the fact that we were starving. The waitress kept our water filled and checked up on us a lot. The udon was a tad bit too salty for me, but maybe I'll try something the next time I go there.
author: Brenda C.

description: Delicious!!  Order any of the special rolls.  All are explosions of flavor.  Moon Dog has just the right bit of spiciness.  Mango Hamachi always has perfectly ripe mango that marries delectably with the fish.  49er is a simply elegant assemblage of salmon, lemon, and avocado.  Perfect salmon and carpaccio thin lemon.  The roll is definitely more than the sum of its parts.  Kanpachi, Hirame, Tai, Salmon, Tuna nigiri ALL amazing!  A little pricey.  But worth every penny.  I think it is better to eat in than order to go.  To go orders never seem to taste quite the same.  Maybe it is because to go orders have less sauce so there isn't a big mess in the containers??
author: Keeping It Real K.

description:
Why pay so much for a knock-off sushi restaurant? 

This place charges way too much for what you can get.  But that being said, the quality of the fish is not in dispute - perhaps that's reason enough to go.  Don't bother ordering regular dishes.  I'm just sick of places that take too many short-cuts to improve their margins.

Go somewhere where you get what you pay for - like Murasaki for something authentic or if you want value go to Okina.
author: yohs m.

description: standard bento lunch....decent sizing and portions....large fatty packed rolls...assume korean operated....teriyaki chicken meal....hefty sliced stacks...completely coated thick teriyaki saucing....texture and chicken slight sub-par....coming with miso and salad.....bento box presentation at par...order of tempura and saba....tempura coating fine and mackerel fried crisp...same salad and miso....rolls compressed tight and filling...ariake acceptable for cooked bento box meals...
author: Hen A.

description:
I was forever pressed to not regard Ariake as highly as I regard other sushi restaurants simply because Jin, the Chef/owner is Korean and not Japanese, but the man is genuinely passionate and committed to providing a very fresh and very extensive selection of fish and a very very fair price. He never ceases to amaze us with his selection of tunas and other less common fish such as shima aji, kampachi, bonito, all consistently served at the perfect temperature, and his Toro is consistently wonderful and a better price than anywhere else.
This is a place to try nigiri after nigiri but if you must try rolls, he has some great ones. My fave? The Moon Dog. The super sweet Korean waitresses are always out to accomodate the guests as well. 
**Great for late night dining.
author: Emily J.

description: Its a small restaurant, however that never doesn't correlate with the food or service.  The chef is very friendly.  The food is delicious.   We were lucky enough to be the only ones dining there during lunch and got their full and undivided attention.  We ordered up rolls, sashimi, sake which satisfied our moaning bellies!
author: S F.

description: Great sushi!!Im very pick about sushi and i love this place! Great chefs,amazing service and most important :amazing food!
author: Tatiane B.

description:
Ariake, I'm so glad I found you. Wanna build my world around you!

Fresh. Good cuts. Super sweet sushi makers. Attentive waitresses. 49er rolls that rock your body.

No, it aint fancy but it never fails to please. Nummers!
author: Jessie S.

description: I tend to initially judge sushi only on whether or not it is rolled correctly. It's an art form. Or like a fine cigar.  Not rolled correctly and you just can't seem to inhale the flavor.  Well, what do I know? I never smoked a cigar, and never rolled my own sushi. Nonetheless, once I encountered that flaccid roll, what was on the inside just didn't count.  2 stars until further notice, maybe the chef was just nervous.
author: Rebecca S.

description: Living in Oakland makes me nostalgic for ariake. They know how to do sushi right! It's always fresh and the fish changes every day. If you're into it ask one of the sushi chefs what's fresh and they will hook it up!  It's not cheap but it is good.
author: Meagan K.

description:
My local favorite! It's more of a mom & pop type sushi joint (not a trendy kind of sushi place) A lot of traditional sushi with just enough of their own creations to keep it fun. Sushi has always been fresh & yummy, and the selection is great.  It's hard to find a sushi restaurant that also serves more of the traditional type Japanese appetizers and side dishes. This is one of 2 places I know in the city that serves yamagake (yum!). 
I discovered this place when Kabuto was full (it's about a block away)  and now prefer Ariake over Kabuto any day.
author: Christine L.

description:
My wife and I met up at Araike with my brother-in-law Tuesday night. 

As has been stated elsewhere, Jin is The Man. If you're a sushi fan, look at the whiteboard, and order whatever suits your tastes from there. Live scallop, shima aji, ocean trout, Scottish salmon, it's all good, and it's all fresh. Ask for the "seafood salad", which I don't think is even on the menu...it's a mix of fish, cut a little smaller than sashimi, some onions, smelt roe, and greens with a slightly spicy sauce. Wonderful!

The seating can be a little cramped at times, but if you're patient and wait for a seat front and center at the bar, you won't regret it!

This is far and away our favorite sushi restaurant in the Bay Area!
author: Ben N.

description: I've been coming to Ariake's for a few years and am never disappointed.  They have a good variety of well priced rolls as well as hard to find specials.  Their hours are pleasantly late, so if you're like me and don't like having to eat by 7:30 on a weekend, then this place is great.
author: cat w.

description: Attention all sushi lovers: Ariake's sushi delivers freshness and satisfaction! The size of the place is small but that does not give you a reason to not come!
author: Nancy N.

description: Best damn sushi in San Francisco. I think I could eat Bob's roll for breakfast, lunch, and dinner for the rest of my life. Jin is the coolest guy ever and he treats us Russians very well. I've eaten at ALOT of sushi places in San Francisco, but this is the place I always recommend to others. Try it now!!!!
author: Andrei B.

description: Thoroughly Impressed!  I just can't believe it took me so long to find this central Richmond gem.  Highlights were the Uni, Blue Fin, Mirugai, fresh house-cured Saba, and the excellent selection of good beer and Sake.  I went for an early lunch with my best friend and had a nice time talking to Jin (The owner) who was very knowledgeable, patient and sensible.  When it comes to good fish at reasonable prices in a friendly and clean environment Ariake gets 5 stars.  This is my new Sushi home.  Definitely worth crossing the park for!
author: Scott S.

description:
ok, i feel guilty saying this,
because i am only supposed to approve of japanese sushi.
I like it here.  
sure it has all the crazy giganto rolls with five kinds of fish and fried asparagus and spider catapillar sf vivian cherryblossom dynamite powpow roll but,
they also have kimpira gobo!  i like the tataki.  i love thinly sliced lemon with my raw fish.
i had a spicy tuna on top of a fried shiso leaf and that was huge and yummy, maybe i would have liked more heat in the spice.
i saw other people's nigiri orders and they looked great, but we already had tons of food.
i have not tried the shio saba, but i am sure it will be good.  
my tip is to order off of the wall behind the chefs.  that is where the fun stuff is.
it's relatively small in there, they were playing koit on the radio.
thats fine by me, i wanted to have a nice meal and conversation with my man.
many places you go for the experience or the unique quisine or scene.
for instance, at oyaji, you really have to pay attention to the sushi chef.
or at genki ramen, my man ends up watching one of the freaking tvs

so yes, i like it here.
author: yayoi s.

description:
I was not at all impressed with the sushi. For sushi that is $12 a roll, I would expect pretty fresh fish. The fish was not fresh and one of them came with a large lump of mayo sauce that did not go down too well.
My friend had the beef teriyaki and he said he had had much better before. The service was not good either. The waiter never asked us if we wanted anything to drink so we finally got his attention after 15 minutes of being there. Then he also messed up on one of the orders. I do not plan on going back.
author: Niki K.

description: Very good food.  Fresh fish, deliciously grilled Hamachi Kama.  This small joint is one of my favorites in the city.  Reasonable prices for the fish quality and food you get.  Everything at this restaurant is done well and although may not be Japanese owned, seems Japanese at heart.
author: Cory C.

description: I really love this place! When I used to go to Ebisu, Jin was always an awesome sushi chef and one busy night when I was at the sushi bar, he looked up and said I feel like I'm a sushi machine and thus me and my husband has coined him " The sushi machine". We have been going there regularly and every time, it's great. The waitresses are so nice and attentive especially with the tea-I love that. The sushi is soo yummy especially one night-the hamachi was like butta! And the specialty rolls like the godzilla is deep fried sushi goodness!The grilled mackerel appetizer was so good too. It does get packed pretty every night of the week so go early. Sushi machine is my man!:)
author: Karen C.

description: came here with a friend to eat some sushi and sashim gave my order  to the Korean waitress asking for 2-3 pieces of sashimi of amber jack salmon toro, and hamachi toro and something else, when i received my place it was 6 piece count of everything, far from what i ordered, i didn't really care at the time knowing i can eat all 24 pieces, i asked the waitress for lemon, but she states" im sorry we don't have any here" which is complete bs knowing the fact that they serve 49 roll which has lemon on top and plus their sushi bar was decorated with slice lemon..... I also orderred their godzilla roll, my first peice i tried tasted like chinatown deep fried bread you put in jook, i had ate about 2 more peices after that not wanting to waste food. my bill came out to be about 110$ which isnt that bad knowing they have really rare fishes and toro on the menu but horrible comunication with the waitress.Had to grab her to say something to give her my card to pay.
author: eric l.

description: this is my favorite japanese restaurant of all time! Delicious!!!! I love their giants roll and spider roll. I always order the same dishes so I don't know how the other dishes taste. All I need is a couple fantastic tasting dishes and I'm sold. I always order spider rolls or rolls with unagi and most other restaurants  make it pretty crappy. This place makes them so good that I'm totally stuffed when I'm done.
author: A C.

description: I've lived around the corner from this place for years.  They have been open now for 13 years, and the first time I tried it was a few weeks ago.  It was the BEST sushi I've ever had.  I went last night for dinner and again today for lunch.  This is no fluke, truely amazing sushi!!!  I highly recommend the tataki salad, AMAZING!
author: Patricia P.

description: Jin is the man. Have the aji if it's fresh. I believe he gets orders in on Tuesdays and Fridays. Service and food are superb. For a unique dish order the "Hit Do Bop"(sp?). Say it like that and they will know what you mean!
author: Adriel L.

description: Fresh sushi that feels like you are having dinner at someones home. Its a nice and cozy environment with great rolls and nigiri. Not much on the ambiance side,  but if you are looking for the freshest catch this is the place. Show up early because is limited seating - especially on weekends. Tastiest unagi this side of  Van Ness, so save some for me!
author: Stacy T.

description: The oysters are not bad . The nameko miso soup was no good ... the miso soup was too bland and did not have enough flavor to it . The albacore tataki was decent . I really like the sauce it was drowned in but the albacore didn't taste that great and the sides edges of the albacore were not seared long enough because they were still white colored .  The fireman roll was very good ... nice and flavorful . It was spicy ; just the way I like it . The salmon and hamachi sashimi were alright but didn't really impress me . Their toro nigiri was so delicious !! ... I could already tell by its looks . The toro was nice and creamy . The ankimo wasn't that good ... it wasn't creamy enough and enough . It kinda tasted like thin cheese . The tasted like it fire cracker roll was alright ... it really tasted like it was on one of those shrimp crackers . The dynamite roll wasn't that good ... the tempura was too thick . Sushi Raw's dynamite roll tastes better . My friend and I ordered a hot sake but it wasn't hot ... it was lukewarm . The sake tasted alright ... not too strong . Maybe it's just me but it tasted like their was a hint of banana in it . The green tea cheesecake was not bad . If  decide to come here , I would definitely recommend getting their toro . It's expensive but well worth it .
author: Eileen L.

description: DELICIOUS. Sashmi is the way to go...amazing toro and hamachi. Everything was delicious. Bob's roll...mmm.
author: Gigi H.

description:
wonderful little place with fresh yummy rolls and nigiri, delicately made. 
the chicken teriyaki here is the best--light yet tasty, not smothered in sodium like at other places...
can also finish up the meal with an assortment of mochi ice cream =]
author: K W.

description:
only been here once, but the service was on the spot, and the food was above par. wasn't expecting much with the tiny restaurant, but it's well lit, has an interesting menu, and is only a few blocks over from my place.

being kind of in the middle of nowhere on the Geary strip, finding yourself here might be unlikely, but you gotta hit a place at least once.

---

-24 June 2007 edit-

i have to drop to three stars. i want to like ariake, and say its wonderful, but i just cant. really, i cant find anything special about the place, and the food it decent, but doesnt make me happy the way the hamachi pear at kabuto does. just just pops in my head as average.
author: Darrell L.

description: Yes! This place is awesome.  We had the dragon roll, firecraker and moondog and they were all top notch. We are putting this in our monthly rotation. I can't wait to go back!
author: Kat L.

description: Ariake rocks.  We've become regulars here now.  Their sushi is consistently excellent ... just the right amount of sushi rice, always the perfect texture, and fresh, large pieces of fish on the nigiri orders.  They also have a fairly extensive assortment of rolls with creative names, like "Bob."  Good sushi is never inexpensive, but Ariake provides a real value.  For a party of two for dinner, you can expect to pay between $50-$70 (that's for both people), including drinks (sake or Japanese beer).
author: Sherry N.

description: Let me preface this with saying that I am a sushi snob. I know, I can't help myself. And coming from LA, I've been spoiled with a good number of top notch sushi places to choose from. In SF, however, a good sushi bar is hard to come by. I've done my research, asked around... and wound up here. I've been back several times, usually to dine in, occasionally to-go. Their butterfish is incredible. That is pretty much what keeps me coming back. And they have a good monk fish dish. Otherwise, their sushi is mediocre. It does have that good hole-in-the-wall neighborhood vibe.  But I come here because I have yet to find my spot for sushi in the city. (It's all about Kirala in Berkeley).
author: Nina H.

description: The decor is nothing to write home about, but Ariake serves some of the freshest sushi and innovative maki in the city. Definitely order the live scallop appetizer if it's available. They also have a decent array of sakes for your quaffing pleasure. Not cheap, but well worth it if you're serious about your fish.
author: Eric G.

description: Pretty standard reasonably priced Richmond sushi.  The chefs and waitress were super nice, but one of the dishes we ordered (special roll with sea urchin and unagi) was nasty.  It tasted like a burnt shoelace.  A new shoelace.  Toxic.
author: Mr. G.

description: I have been here a few times and I have always been impressed with the service and most of all the fresh fish and sushi rolls.  Jin, the owner, is very welcoming along with the rest of the staff.  The staff is very knowledgable about the dishes and can help advise you if you are new to sushi.  I have gone here with my wife and I have also brought out of town co-workers here for a nice San Francisco surprise.
author: Todd Z.

description:
This place is fantastic, but you have to know a couple things:

Get to know the owner, Jin. He's ultra friendly, and your food tastes better as you get friendlier. Yeah, the "it's who you know" rule extends to this restaurant, too.

The rolls are great, but the treats are in the nigiri. The geoduck, the toro, the salmon, the tai, all that stuff is mmm mmm goodness. I'm getting hungry thinking about it.

The one roll that comes to mind is the hamachi mango. Good stuff. The mild sweet/sour tart of the mango gives the roll a nice kick. One roll that I forgot the name of (I want to say Moon Dog) has this baked pile of creamy sauce+various seafood components. It's one of their few warm rolls, and has so many wonderful and rich tastes.

This place isn't all perfect, though. While the food isn't overly salty, I think they add MSG or salt or something to the rice, because I always leave this place really really thirsty, and I'm drinking tea the whole time! This place is also pretty slow, mostly because there's two main guys making the food and it's a popular place.

My tip for getting the most out of this place is ordering different kinds of food. I'm not talking getting the salmon and then getting the tuna. I'm talking get a couple rolls, get a few nigiri, get a hand roll. And seriously, get to know Jin. Early on, I made both mistakes. I was with friends and we ordered only rolls and didn't know Jin. The food was quite blah. I was brought back by a friend who knows Jin very well and she also ordered a good variety of rolls and nigiri, and I've been hooked since!
author: Rick L.

description:
Don't order from the menu...

Let the chef take care of you at the bar... the off menu food is excellent. fish is so fresh and the place is always packed.  some of the Sauce on their rolls might not be the best choice (like the sweet mayo - more like american style)

Just ask the chef for special of the night. and Do Not complain about the price... normally spend $30-$50 per. If that's too much, just EXPECT less then  :D
author: Alvin C.

description:
So having just graduated from USF and wanting to celebrate with my girlfriend and friends, me, her, and her roommate walked to Ariake from her place. I've passed by this place many times but I finally had the chance to try it.

As we walked in I noticed the restaurant was decorated nicely, and they even had a TV at the sushi bar playing Game 4 of the Lakers-Nuggets series. We ordered hot tea, hot sake, Sapporo and water to start off with, and they gave us edamamme as well without us asking. I started off with an Ariake roll and tai nigiri (red snapper). The roll was great; the seaweed salad complimented the spicy tuna, and the red snapper was soft and melted in my mouth. Next, I had tamago, shima aji (yellow jack) and a dynamite roll (deep fried, spicy yellowtail, salmon and tuna). The spiciness of the roll did not overpower the taste of the fish,  the egg in the tamago was fresh and the yellow jack was fresh. Finally, I had aji (jack mackerel). Once again the nigiri was soft and tasty. The bill was not expensive considering how much sushi we had, and since I drank most of the sake and beer, I left full and a little drunk. This place is a great neighborhood sushi joint and I will definitely be back.
author: Theo T.

description:
went back to ariake again tonight and wasn't quite so enamored. my dining companion (my mom!) and i ordered the mango hamachi roll, the ms. vivian roll, and the cherry blossom roll. the mango hamachi definitely wasn't as good as it was the first time (thought it looked lovely), and the other two rolls were strangely spicy. i've had a cherry blossom roll before at other places, and this tasted nothing like it was supposed to taste. 

i also thought the service was kindof off, though my mom just thought they were being tentative. this is definitely a neighborhood restaurant though, and the waitstaff seems to know many of the diners. 

kindof sad about this realization since i thought this was a new favorite. just have to keep searching!!
author: Eryn L.

description: The tuna tataki here is amazing ... seared white tuna with onions and ponzu sauce ... so simple and yet so delicious.  The other specialty rolls are pretty tasty although I wouldn't all any of them must-eats.  The strangest one was the Lion King ... crab roll with baked salmon on top ... it tasted good but was just a little off somehow.  A small place so good to make a reservation if you can.
author: Melinda C.

description: Out of hundreds of sushi places I've been to, this one makes the best tatake salad. Lot's of places don't even have it. The atmosphere is nice, small cozy place with friendly people. They're not very cheap, but most of the stuff from the menu is delish!!!
author: Anna Z.

description: One of better Japanese restaurants I've tried, the sushi was very fresh and its a pretty tiny place. We were eating when the staff was having family dinner, kind of funny. Prices are average, should definitely check it out.
author: Lily K.

description: The 49er roll had a weird herb added to it, couldn't figure out what it was..  Ariake roll was good though.  Overall, it was unmemorable.  The next time my roommate went, he got really bad food poisoning... So I guess that's the end of that place for me.
author: Derrick V.

description: I LOVE IT HERE, this place is always my favorite sushi place to go to when I celebrate a small family event like birthdays. When i go here, I order the Ankimo(monkfish liver) which is amazing here... This place is also very consistent every time I go here. The only thing I don't like about it, is the place is alittle small but other than that everything is great. This place is the best sushi place Ive been to in S.F and I would recommend this place to anybody. :D
author: Justin L.

description:
shashimi is always fresh!  rolls are very creative and pretty - i love the monkey roll with uni!  the baby oysters are the best!  hamachi kama is cooked to perfection and it comes with the sauce!

owner is very friendly!  this is one of my fave restaurants!  =)
author: Kristen T.

description:
firecracker roll is the best. 

parking is a b*tch.

the waitress named lisa is the best.
author: Rosalee C.

description: I've lived across the street from this restaurant for years and was really excited to finally try it. We got seated right away since we decided to sit at the bar. It took a while for the waitress to take our order but we weren't bothered by that since we weren't in a hurry. We ordered 3 rolls; the 49'er, Ariake, and Dynamite. We received our first two rolls maybe within 15 min. I noticed that they only had two chefs so we didn't say anything when we didn't receive our third roll. It was probably 30 min later and one of the waiters asked if we wanted our check. We told him we didn't receive our third roll. 15 min after that I figured they forgot and we decided to get the check. We told the waitress that we didn't receive the roll and just wanted the check. When she told the chef he proceeded to tell us in front of the whole restaurant  that he gave us the roll. I was shocked that he was suggesting we just didn't want to pay for it. It is a small place and the entire restaurant was starring at us. We were being nice by giving them time to get us our roll because they were busy and then they go off and pretty much act like we were trying to steal from them. I even tipped well because I know it wasn't the waitresses fault, but I would never got back to this place again. They were very disrespectful and rude when it was their mistake! I decided to start a yelp account just so I can write this review. Just beware that if they make a mistake you might get called out for it in front of the entire restaurant.
author: Nicole T.

description:
Absolutely one of the best sushi restaurants in SF.  I've been a regular at Ariake since 2004 and although I am not proud of it, I have to admit I've tried many other places.  None of them can beat the sushi here.  A couple may come close, but are far more expensive.  

Jin serves absolutely the freshest sushi and his creations are great.  Hamachi Mango Roll, Moondog Roll, Uni, Super White Tuna, Scallop, Amaebi, Aji, Kampaji...I could go on and on.  

Eating here on Friday nights after a long week made my weekends that much better!!!

Thanks Jin!
author: Clinton J.

description:
great service, friendly waitress.. always coming by to check how things are going...

as for the food... hamachi mango and firecracker... mmmm.. mmm... mmmm... mmmm..
author: s d.

description: This is the best Sushi restaurant in San Francisco.  If you are about the quality of the fish and food, this is the place for you. Traditional ambiance, not trendy. Just really good food.
author: Becca F.

description: One of my favorite Richmond sushi joints. I usually get takeout here since it's so close to my place. The sushi and rolls are the best bets over the other stuff like tonkatsu. The fish is pretty darn fresh and tasty. I agree with previous reviewer on the side salad, I get that everytime - I think it's their dressing. I'll admit one time I even drank some of the leftover dressing at the bottom of the bowl...anywho...I recommend it.
author: Brian S.

description: I ate here earlier tonight with my girlfriend.  It had been recommended by some friends of ours who eat at Ariake all the time.  The Sushi was excellent.  Very fresh and inventive.  However, the service was strangely pushy.  We ordered our dinner and the waitress remained at our table, pressuring us to buy something else.  She really wouldn't leave until we ordered another dish.  I felt uncomfortable.  If I eat here again, I will get take out.
author: Richard N.

description: Having this restaurant seconds away from my doorstep might make me biased, but it truly is a fabulous place for sushi. I know former locals that continue to return to Ariake time and time again to indulge in the delicious rolls. I order the mango hamachi roll every time and am never disappointed. Edamame is complimentary and they indulge me in my sake bombs. There is no pretension here and though the place is bustling, if there is ever a wait, it is usually not more than 5-7 minutes.
author: Renee B.

description: I eat here pretty often, 'cause I work across the street at the tattoo shop. I've never had a bad experience or meal here. Everyone is always friendly, the food is always good. Sometimes we get it to go and eat at the shop. The other day I was in there with the wife and we got, among other things, something called tatake, which I believe was some kind of tuna. it was kind of expensive, I thought, but ordered it anyway because I was feeling extravagant. As it turns out, it was actually kind of a value! There was a ring of fish all the way around the edge of the plate and then  a little mound of it in the center on top of grated daikon, green onion and watercress, I think. It was fucking awesome, and could have filled us up by itself had we only known. As it was we ended up gorging ourselves, having not anticipated the size of this dish and ordering a shitload of other stuff too. Anyway, the fish was marinated heavily in something really good, maybe including rice vinegar(?). Man, it was good. I could really go for some right now. I guess if you're not into marinated stuff you wouldn't like it, but I am and I did. Everything else was great also. I'm hungry.
author: jason s.

description: The 1st time I went here I loved it. Then about a month ago it was very blah. What happened to the food quality?
author: Rob D.

description: Kabuto (a block away) gets all the press, but Ariake is just as good if not better.  I would give six stars if I could.  Go for the live scallops and the toro.  Never had a bad thing here.
author: Greg L.

description: Such a good value. When I feel like pigging out of uni toro and other stuff, then I come here.  It makes me happy.
author: M K.

description: The best sushi restaurant in San Francisco bar none , Gene is great and creative , i am a sushi lover and travel often , i made it as a rule to try sushi where ever i go , in my opinion Gene is the best sushi chef i ever met.
author: frank j.

description: So, even 3 months ago I would have given this restaurant "5 stars" as the fish is always fresh and delicious and the prices are pretty reasonable for the quality.  However, the last time I brought a friend there, I felt like we were treated differently because we got the "sampler platter" instead of the a la carte items written on the wall.  The chef who had always been so friendly and nice to me was suddenly looking at me (and my friend) like we were second class citizens.  The sampler was ok (your standard tuna, salmon, halibut, etc) but I almost felt guilty for not getting the gourmet stuff.  A reputable sushi chef will do his best to impress you with his work, no matter if you are paying  10 or 1000 bucks for dinner.
author: Lisa K.

description: Good sushi, probably fresher fish than a lot of places in the city and especially on Geary, but the server kept forgetting our order/requests for water, miso soup, etc. which was frustrating.  I wasn't really into the rolls that were cooked, but the raw stuff was awesome.  I love that my friends love sushi (which is the reason I was here in the first place).  Definitely wouldn't recommend this place for big parties (we had 19 people).  Get the Moon Dog roll - super good!
author: Margie N.

description: jin is ex sushi chef from ebisu long long time ago. and finnally open his own sushi rest. most of the sushi are the same roll but cheaper. the service is always great. ask jin what fresh today and he told you the truth. ask for his new innovation sushi and follow. you not gonna regret it! he never put me down everytime i go there.
author: sherly A.

description: Very simple and very enjoyable restaurant. I really enjoyed the Sushis there which were at the right temperature, well cut and with a perfect texture. This place would deserve four stars if only I did not find an insect in my salad, and they did not come up with a miserable excuse "it was a piece of dry onion". I have never seen onions with wings :) But despite this important detail, it is a place worth trying.
author: Cedrick C.

description: Been eating sushi all over the world for thirty years and for value, freshness, and service, Ariake is hard to beat. Highly recommend Ariake.
author: Bill D.

description: food is very fresh and owner Jin is very nice, will go back again when i want to eat japanese.
author: larry l.

description: Great people, great service, great food.  I love their rolls, bento boxes, sushi...everything!!!  They have this Ms Vivian roll that I order all the time, and also this salmon with really thin slices of lemon....SSOOO refreshing!!!!  I highly recommend.
author: mooncake w.

description: You know how everyone has a place....I would say this sushi place is "OUR PLACE", meaning my bf and I. They have the best sake sushi, which my bf and I love sooo much. They have a variety of specialty sushi. The chef's are really nice, and the service her is ok. I only come here for the food. If you want something cozy, nice and affordable place to eat sushi, try this place. I think you'll like it....
author: Christina O.

description: Great, small sushi restaurant in slightly out of the way location on Geary. Yum!
author: Jennifer E.

description: after buying our house in the richmond 2 years ago i have been searching for good sushi.  i finally found it.  i liked it the first time i went there - i loved the last time.  it's get better and better.   the tuna tataki is so good.  it's one of those dishes that after you eat the last bite you can't wait to come back and eat it again.  the rolls are yummy and some are visually stunning.  i love shiso leaf and the deep fry it here and pile spicy tuna on top.  they are very generous with the fish.  you will not be dissappointed!
author: jeannie t.
